speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I would like to add my support for the Port Greville shipbuilding museum. This project is being established in an area of high unemployment and will add greatly to the tourism potential of this beautiful part of Nova Scotia.
Located on the shores of the Bay of Fundy, the Port Greville coast was a prominent shipbuilding region in the days of wooden ships at the turn of the century. This museum will pay tribute to this important piece of our history.
The people of the community have come together and raised a substantial part of the costs, as well as donated a large amount of time and labour. Applications for cost sharing have also been made to the Department of Industry, Science and Technology and the Department of Communications. I will be meeting with the appropriate officials to press for approval of these requests.
The project is genuine, it is worth while, and it is very much needed. The groundwork has been done by the local people and now is the time for government to provide much needed assistance.

[Editor's Note: Member spoke in Inuktitut]

Mr. Speaker, last week the Inuit of the eastern and central Arctic voted in favour of ratifying their land claim. Linked to that land claim is a process to create the new territory of Nunavut. The Inuit of Nunavut have expressed their desire to be more active partners in the Canadian federation. They have said they want more control over their lives.
The government must do its part by facilitating the transfer of control. Not only must the government ratify the land claim agreement, it must ensure that adequate resources are dedicated to implementing the agreement. Barely 12 hours after the vote results were announced, concerns were raised about inadequate federal implementation funding. Sufficient implementation funding is critical to the success of the land claim agreement.
I urge the government to be fair and generous in these financial negotiations. Do not deny the people of Nunavut the financial resources they need to fulfil the promise of Nunavut.

Mr. Speaker, this week is a special week to promote public awareness of drug abuse. This provincial and local initiative is aimed at making us more aware of the impact of alcohol and other drugs on individuals.
Drug-related problems have an impact, either directly or indirectly, on all parts of our society. No single group or agency has the requisite resources to deal with these problems. Only by forming alliances and co-ordinating the efforts of individuals, groups, communities and all levels of government will we ever be able to limit the harm done by alcohol and other drugs.
The government supports this special drug awareness week, and I would encourage hon. members and all Canadians to take part in the activities and special events taking place this week in communities across Canada.

November 18, 1992

Mr. Speaker, the subcommittee examining the North American free trade deal has no advertising budget and is not even an open process.
It is disturbing that the government managed to find $3 million to advertise the NAFTA deal but refused to approve even $15,000 to advertise where and when the subcommittee meetings were taking place.
I was surprised that when the New Democratic Party proposed that the committee hold hearings in every province and territory of this country the Liberals voted with the government that the committee should not travel to my home province of Saskatchewan, to New Brunswick, to Prince Edward Island, to Newfoundland, to Vancouver Island, to northern Ontario, or even to Toronto, Hamilton or Montreal. They also voted against allowing the committee to visit the various communities which have been devastated by the U.S.-Canada Free Tirade Agreement.
Why does the Liberal Party not want an open process? I can only guess it is because the Liberals and the Tories do not want Canadians to know that they both support anti-worker, anti-environment trade deals.

Mr. Speaker, the Canadian middle class is at a crossroads. Thxes are high and confidence is low.
A poll this week highlighted a disturbing reality. More than half of the people polled believed their children would be worse off than they were. This must and can be changed for if the Canadian middle class dies, Canada dies.
How do we change things? The federal government alone cannot do it through fairer taxes and spending cuts, both of which we must accomplish. Others have a
role as well. Provincial governments can do the same and reduce the burden of government on middle class Canadians.
The private sector can take more risks with wealth and job creation. Unions can become partners in economic recovery. NDP governments can scrap pro-labour legislation and replace it with the right-to-work laws. Individual Canadians can accept more responsibility for their own lives, reducing the expectation of government hand-outs which this country can no longer afford.
It is time all of us did all we could to reaffirm the backbone of Canada, the diligent, industrious and disciplined middle class.

Mr. Speaker, the economic recession which has held Canada within its tight grip for over two years is a direct result of poor management of the Canadian economy by this government.
The government's mishandling of the Canadian economy has cost thousands of jobs and has increased the reliance of Canadians on food banks and other social services.
In my riding of Nipissing there has been a 30 per cent increase in the number of people who have filed new applications for unemployment insurance over the past three months. Hence 400 more Canadians are forced into the endless unemployment lines.
Accompanying this rise in UI claims is a 100 per cent increase in the number of families utilizing the food bank in North Bay since September. The government has done nothing to stimulate the economy and create jobs. The fact remains there are still 1.5 million Canadians who are out of work.
The time has come for the government to acknowledge that its economic policies have failed miserably and to implement job creation programs which will stimulate the economy and give Canadians hope for the future.
November 18, 1992

Mr. Speaker, there is good news for farmers and there is good news for free traders from coast to coast in Canada.
A binational panel established under the free trade agreement rules recently ordered the United States to stop a countervailing action against Canadian hogs and to refund the duties already collected. The refund will total $10 million but is only a small part of the victory.
The major win comes with the decision that Americans had no right to say that Canada's national tripartite program gave Canadian farmers an unfair market advantage. As one Manitoba hog producer said: "With free trade we would have lost this last level of appeal".
The free trade agreement has doubled agricultural exports from Canada to the United States creating many new jobs. I rest my case.

Mr. Speaker, recently, Mr. Marcel Gervais, Archbishop of Ottawa and president of the Canadian Conference of Catholic Bishops, wrote to the Secretary of State for External Affairs to condemn the current political situation in Haiti.
Mr. Gervais wrote that on September 24, Mr. Willy Romelus, Bishop of Jeremie in Haiti, narrowly escaped an assassination attempt while spending the night in the rectory of the parish of Des Irois.
Because the situation in Haiti continues to deteriorate and the number of victims of repression is increasing, the Canadian Conference of Catholic Bishops has asked the Canadian government to maintain its position on nonrecognition of the de facto government in Haiti.
We must publicly condemn the harassment, threats and daily violations of human rights. We must condemn the present authorities who allow this to happen. Decisive action is necessary so that the Organization of American States can intervene actively and effectively.
We must ask the UN to support this exercise. The Canadian Conference of Catholic Bishops is also asking the government to tighten the embargo on military arms and equipment which the junta in Haiti is still able to buy.

Mr. Speaker, a while ago, following a tragic incident that took her sister Marie-Eve's life, a young girl decided to do something positive for a non-violent society.
Virginie Lariviere decided that she had enough of seeing violence on television. She was not the only one who had had enough. Nearly a million and a half Canadians decided to support her efforts to eliminate violence on television.
Virginie Lariviere is a living example of what we can do to change things and improve our society. Instead of feeling sorry for her fate and turning inward or complaining, she decided to get involved and fight violence.
We often tell our young people to get involved and do something. Virginie did that admirably and we have no right to remain indifferent to her request and the wishes of the Canadian people.
We must now take concrete action and show Virginie as well as all young people in this country that she did a good thing, the right thing and that change is possible if we really want it.
Congratulations to all the Virginie Larivieres in Canada.

Mr. Speaker, everything indicates that the federal government intends to subsidize PWA and Canadian International.
Such a decision is contrary to the interests of Canadians and Quebecers. The president of the Montreal Chamber of Commerce, Bernard Roy, said that the two carriers should be merged so we do not have to support two lame ducks.

The mayor of Montreal says that it is unthinkable to subsidize only one airline and the same, if not more, financial assistance would have to be given to Air Canada.
I agree. This bail-out is illogical and sheer waste. The federal government is not authorized to further indebt Canada and Quebec just to get votes.

Mr. Speaker, Virginie Lariviere is here in Ottawa today with her parents and the Conservative member for Terrebonne in order to table, in memory of her sister Marie-Eve, a petition signed by over a million people calling for the elimination of violence on television and in our society.
The people of the federal riding of Abitibi strongly supported Virginie's effort to have violent movies on television regulated by March 1993.
I met Virginie today and I can assure you, Mr. Speaker and all members of this House, that Virginie Lariviere's team will apply all the pressure needed to win this cause.

Mr. Speaker, the Liberal trade critic said to Canadians last night on CBC that it was no big deal if the North American free trade agreement was approved.
It is a big deal to Canadian seniors and families. They will have to pay the higher drug prices that NAFTA dictates through Bill C-91. It is a big deal to provincial health ministers and taxpayers who will pay at least $800 million more in increased drug prices.
What has happened to the federal minister of health who promised he would take the concerns of provincial ministers of health about Bill C-91 to cabinet?
Even if the Liberal trade critic still thinks it is no big deal, the word NAFTA means all Canadians will pay more for drugs. Seniors, families and taxpayers all know
what the Liberals do not understand. More for drug prices is a big deal.

Mr. Speaker, I bring you urgent and pressing news which I have learned from Calgary. I know that you are keenly interested in the future of the nation which is being plotted in the lavish Reform Party headquarters.
Last week the leader who flip-flopped said the federal government should not get involved in the Canadian Airlines issue. This week he says we should. What will he say next week?
Once he was against the GST, then he supported it and now he wants it both ways: Keep it and get rid of it. Once he supported Senate reform, then he campaigned to kill Senate reform.
Many Albertans are asking: What does the Reform Party stand for? We are quite well aware of what it is against.

speakerposition: Deputy House Leader of the Official Opposition; Liberal Party Deputy House Leader
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, do you remember these immortal words?
There will be jobs for Liberals and NDPers too after I have been Prime Minister for 15 years and I cannot find a living, breathing Tory left to appoint.
Who said that?

speakerposition: Deputy House Leader of the Official Opposition; Liberal Party Deputy House Leader
speechtext:
It was the Prime Minister who said that.
Last week, he was seen scraping the bottom of the barrel or should I say the patronage trough when he appointed his former baby-sitter and chauffeur, Michael McSweeney, to a $100,000 a year job.
Shame.

speakerposition: Deputy House Leader of the Official Opposition; Liberal Party Deputy House Leader
speechtext:
He appointed his pal, Keith Morgan, to a 10-year appointment on the parole board. Keith got a life sentence to the parole board.
Now the Prime Minister has appointed a former separatist cabinet minister, Jocelyne Ouellette, to a $140,000 high-flying job at the space agency.
Canadians are wondering who will be next. Will it be the hairdresser to the court of appeals, or Clover the poodle to the board of Petro-Canada?
November 18, 1992

We are all waiting anxiously and Clover is salivating at the thought.

speakeroldname: Hon. Jean Chretien (Leader of the Opposition):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, everybody knows that the new Clinton administration to be installed in two months holds the position of wanting to make some major changes to NAFTA.
Yesterday, the minister for trade said that this government wants to proceed very rapidly with ratification, even without knowing the position of the new administration. He is almost as irresponsible as the NDP members who want to tear up the agreement without knowing if there will be any changes at all.
I want to ask the Prime Minister if he will agree with us that it would be better for Canada and for everyone to wait until we know exactly what the position of the Clinton administration will be before asking Parliament to pass this bill in the House of Commons.

speakeroldname: Hon. Michael Wilson (Minister of Industry, Science and Technology and Minister for International TVade):
speakerposition: Minister for International Trade; Minister of Industry, Science and Technology
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I thought when my friend was standing up to ask me a question on trade that he was going to comment on the very good news we had this morning, with exports to the United States up so far this year, a
10.5	per cent increase.
There is a 10.5 per cent increase in trade to a country that is having a slow economy. It clearly shows the benefits of the free trade agreement and it clearly shows the foresight of this government in entering into a free trade agreement. It also clearly demonstrates that Canadian companies are competing very effectively in taking advantage of the opportunities that the free trade agreement has presented to them.
Regarding the specific question of my hon. friend, he has not stated accurately what I said in committee last night. I said that we would be ready to proceed with legislation at the end of January or early in February, but before taking that final decision we would want to see exactly what the status of the process was in the United States and also to see precisely what Mr. Clinton might have in mind with these parallel agreements that he has talked about.
Oral Questions
That was the position that I stated on two occasions to his trade critic last night. It was not as he has just put it in the House today.

speakeroldname: Hon. Jean Chretien (Leader of the Opposition):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I would like to ask the minister this question.
Would it not be more logical to wait until he knows exactly what the results of the negotiations will be with the new Clinton agreement before coming to this House? In doing what he is doing, he is playing his chips before negotiating. We are asking the minister to go back and negotiate. He should renegotiate not only environmental and labour standards, but he should renegotiate a clear independence for Canada on energy policy. He should negotiate what is a subsidy and what is dumping.

speakeroldname: Hon. Michael Wilson (Minister of Industry, Science and Technology and Minister for International TVade):
speakerposition: Minister for International Trade; Minister of Industry, Science and Technology
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I think if my friend took that position he would be playing right into the hands of the U.S. government. He would be saying that we are prepared to open up everything, that we are prepared to open up culture, health care and all these things that my hon. friend is concerned about.
We have said and what I said quite clearly at the committee last night is that the agreement that we agreed upon with the United States government and the Mexican government is an agreement among three sovereign governments. We expect that the Clinton administration will honour that agreement, and we are proceeding with NAFTA as it stands. What happens on the peripheral agreements, the supplementary agreements, are matters that can be discussed. We are already discussing them with the current administration. But the NAFTA stands.

speakeroldname: Hon. Jean Chretien (Leader of the Opposition):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I do not understand the minister when he says that the U.S. administration will ask for changes and then claims that the agreement will remain the same. If any changes are accepted by the Americans and the Mexicans, this means a new agreement. My question for the minister is this: Why does he not wait and see what the final position of the new U.S. administration will be, before saying that we are entirely satisfied, because that is not the case. Canadians are not satisfied with the agreement between Canada, Mexico and the United States.

Oral Questions

speakeroldname: Hon. Michael Wilson (Minister of Industry, Science and Technology and Minister for International TVade):
speakerposition: Minister for International Trade; Minister of Industry, Science and Technology
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, my hon. friend is saying be prepared to open up the NAFTA. We are not prepared to open up the NAFTA. The people who are affected by the NAFTA, the North American free trade agreement, people who are in the manufacturing sector, the forest products sector, the automotive sector, the cultural sector, have said that this is a good agreement. We are not prepared to open it up because we could stand the possibility of weakening that agreement.
If that is the position of the Liberal Party of Canada- He says he wants to negotiate. I am waiting to hear from his trade critic what areas the Liberal Party would like to renegotiate, and how it would like to renegotiate it. I think he will find that it is not possible to negotiate a better deal than we have already.

Mr. Speaker, in September I asked the Minister for International Trade to table the government's impact studies on the North American free trade agreement. Instead, the minister tabled a series of promotional papers.
Having now initialled the agreement, and knowing that free trade inevitably does bring dislocation, why is the government unwilling to table today, to share with Canadians, the real impact studies which indicate where jobs will be lost and what specific adjustment assistance will be provided to help those workers and businesses adversely affected?

speakeroldname: Hon. Michael Wilson (Minister of Industry, Science and Technology and Minister for International TVade):
speakerposition: Minister for International Trade; Minister of Industry, Science and Technology
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, so that the House is fully aware of this, last night I tabled about eight or nine studies that had already been made available, which my friend in the New Democratic Party had forgotten that we had done for the House.
In addition to that, I was prepared to discuss the Finance Department report on this, which covers extensively the benefits that will flow from the North American free trade agreement.
In addition, I tabled a bibliography, a listing of some 200 or 300 publications that have been done as to the
effect of the North American free trade agreement on the three countries. Surely my hon. friend could have a very effective and very productive time in reviewing all of those.
My hon. friend talks about the impacts. The best way that we could understand the impacts of the free trade agreement was to discuss with the companies and the industries affected as we went through the negotiations just precisely how the various elements of the agreement were going to affect them. This is exactly what we did through the broadest possible consultation process that any government has ever conducted on the negotiations of a trade agreement.
On the question of adjustment-

speakerposition: Speaker of the House of Commons
speechtext: I think we should move ahead.

The minister knows very well that there are impact studies that analyse the real impact, not a promotional impact but the real impact, of the free trade agreement on Canadian workers and on Canadian business.
One aspect has been brought forward today by the Conference Board of Canada which has stated, and I quote: "As a result of the Canada-U.S. Free Trade Agreement, many Canadian firms are facing fewer barriers to trade with the United States than they face within Canada".
The minister wants to speak about reports. The Macdonald commission, the de Grandpre report, the working group on prosperity have all asked the same question: If free trade with the United States and Mexico is good for Canada, why is free trade not good within Canada?
When will this government commit to a specific timetable and to specific measures to dismantle these harmful barriers within our country?

speakeroldname: Hon. Michael Wilson (Minister of Industry, Science and Technology and Minister for International TVade):
speakerposition: Minister for International Trade; Minister of Industry, Science and Technology
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, my hon. friend keeps talking about wanting to know the real impact of free trade. The real impact of free trade was announced this morning with the announcement that Canadian exports to the United States in the first nine months of this year were up 10.5 per cent compared to the first nine months last year. That is the real impact.

My hon. friend talks about interprovincial trade barriers. I am sure that he read this morning the very good news that the federal and provincial agriculture ministers have taken the very important first step in dealing with the trade barriers between the provinces in the area of agricultural policy.
We agree with the hon. member that it is important that we eliminate these. This was a primary objective that we had in the discussions on the constitutional reform proposals. We were not successful there, but I have a meeting, I believe it is the first week of-

speakerposition: Speaker of the House of Commons
speechtext: I would ask that ministers try to speed up their answers.

Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Prime Minister.
It is clear since the House came back that this government has no new ideas on the economy, no new ideas to get Canadians back working. By the way, the real impact studies that we have seen are the impact that the Canada-U.S. trade deal has had with the loss of 350,000 manufacturing jobs and the high unemployment in this country. We have seen the impact of the Canada-U.S. trade deal.
I am very surprised to hear the Leader of the Opposition talk about having the opinions of Mr. Clinton taken into consideration when the Liberal Party and the Conservative Party on the subcommittee on trade have refused to have hearings on NAFTA in every province and every territory so that Canadians can have their say on the NAFTA deal.
I want to ask the Prime Minister this. It is now in the government's hands. Will the government ensure that there is an open process, not by invitation only, so that Canadians in every part of this country can express their views on the proposed NAFTA trade arrangements?

Mr. Speaker, my hon. friend refers to Canadians in every part of the country in terms of trade. Obviously the consultations that will go on at the special committee will be receiving representations from interested parties.
In respect of individual provinces and regions, my hon. friend will want to note that in the January-September
Oral Questions
period the 1992 merchandise exports to the United States are 10.5 per cent ahead of January-September 1991, on course to generate a full-year figure of $119 billion and substantially exceed the 1990 all-time record high of $110.5 billion. Now, Mr. Speaker-
Order.

Mr. Speaker, my hon. friend asks me a question and yet members of the NDP object to the answer.
Canada's merchandise exports to the United States have been at record levels in every month so far this year, hitting an all-time monthly high of $10,299 billion in September.
I will be happy to provide my friend with a breakdown by province where every Canadian province has substantially increased its exports to the United States since the coming into effect of the free trade agreement.

A supplementary, Mr. Speaker, for the Prime Minister.
Clearly there is both a great difference of opinion and experience about the results of the Canada-U.S. trade deal. I say to the Prime Minister: Given yesterday that the subcommittee examining the North American trade deal voted against a New Democratic motion to hold hearings in every province and territory, which means that there will not be hearings in Saskatchewan, the Yukon, the Northwest Territories, Vancouver Island, Newfoundland, New Brunswick, Prince Edward Island, Toronto, Hamilton and-
Oh, oh.

speakerposition: Speaker of the House of Commons
speechtext: The hon. member has referred to something in a committee but I do not think a question has been put. Is the hon. member putting a question?

Yes, Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Prime Minister.
Why will the Prime Minister and this government not initiate an open door policy to hear what Canadians have to say on NAFTA, which is surely the economic constitution of Canada. Will he make sure they are not just hearings by invitation only but that there are hearings in every province and territory in the country?

November 18, 1992
Oral Questions
Mr. Speaker, as I have already indicated, I am sure that the minister and the committee make their own rules with respect to hearings.
Oh, oh.
I apologize for that hilarious remark, Mr. Speaker.
More nerve than a bad toothache.

Exactly, Brian. When they meet they will probably want to consider some simple facts. When Albertans come before the committee, my hon. friends from the NDP can ask whether it is true or not that Alberta's exports to the United States have risen exactly 30 per cent from 1988 to 1991.
How about Saskatchewan?
My hon. friend says, how about Saskatchewan. Saskatchewan's exports have increased 18 per cent from $2.0 billion to $2.3 billion.

Mr. Speaker, what the government does not seem to realize is that there are many people in this country who have seen their plants and their jobs move south, who have seen the results of the Canada-U.S. trade deal and want to have a say and to bring forward their experience to parliamentarians who make the decisions on these very important issues.
Do I understand that the Prime Minister is in favour of very limited hearings on the NAFTA deal, and there will not be hearings in every province and territory? Is the Prime Minister in favour of having invitation only hearings for Canadian people on the NAFTA deal?
Mr. Speaker, I am in favour of wide-open discussions on trade agreements. In fact, I am even in favour of elections on trade agreements.
Oh, oh.

Mr. Speaker, my question is directed to the Minister of Industry, Science and Technology.
With its trumped up charges of dumping, the U.S. steel industry has engaged in a fight to the finish with Canadian steelmakers to cut us out of the U.S. market. Recently, representatives of the industry throughout Canada had to publicly speak out against the Canadian government's lack of response and support.
My question is this: Why is this government casting aside Canadian steelmakers? Why will it not do everything it can to safeguard the jobs of thousands of Canadian workers?

speakeroldname: Hon. Michael Wilson (Minister of Industry, Science and Technology and Minister for International TVade):
speakerposition: Minister for International Trade; Minister of Industry, Science and Technology
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I do not know who my hon. friend is talking about. I have met with senior executives of the steel companies, senior executives of the unions, senior representatives from the city of Hamilton and the city of Sault Ste. Marie on occasions during the course of the past year. I have stated very clearly to them the concerns we have with regard to the action that the United States is taking in the question of anti-dumping.
The Prime Minister, myself, our ambassador and other officials in Washington have discussed with the administration the possibility of a U.S.-Canada steel pact similar to the auto pact. We have not given up on the possibilities of that. There is also a possibility that with the change in administration we may have a greater chance of seeing that type of arrangement go forward.
However, these are matters that are continually on our platter. We are also working hard to make sure that the best interests of the steel industry are put forward in our discussions.

Mr. Speaker, representatives of the steel industry went public on a CBC broadcast about 10 days ago and said there was a lack of support from the government. They also clearly said that the imposition of countervail duties by Canada was insufficient.
The minister has now said publicly that he is prepared to support a North American steel pact. We are delighted to hear that. The minister blew it in the NAFTA negotiations. He now has a chance to recoup. Bill Clinton has said that as a condition precedent to his signing NAFTA he wants to see new parallel agreements.
November 18, 1992

Will this government make a condition precedent to us signing NAFTA, the signing of a North American steel pact? Put your money where your mouth is.

speakerposition: Speaker of the House of Commons
speechtext: Perhaps members might all consider exercising just a little bit of self-discipline for the rest of Question Period.

speakeroldname: Hon. Michael Wilson (Minister of Industry, Science and Technology and Minister for International Trade):
speakerposition: Minister for International Trade; Minister of Industry, Science and Technology
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, my hon. friend has to realize that time is of the essence with regard to the matters before the steel industry today. It is essential that we deal with these matters as quickly as possible. That is why we are having meetings with our industry and with the U.S. administration and with the new administration as soon as the appropriate people are in place.
We will continue to do that, but my hon. friend should be very careful in the way he phrases his questions, not to leave the impression that there will be more trade barriers between the United States and Canada. That might make it more difficult for Canadian ship owners to purchase ships and to operate the ships between the two countries.

Mr. Speaker, we agree with the minister that time is of the essence. That is why we have to ask how serious the government is when the Conservative chairman of the steel caucus has not called a meeting in two years. We wonder if his colleagues should not share the concern of the minister that indeed time is of the essence.

Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Prime Minister and it concerns the fact that two years ago he co-chaired the United Nations world summit on children. At that conference he stated that the number one priority of his government was to combat child poverty.
The reality is that in the last 10 years the number of children using food banks in Canada has increased from zero to 700,000.
If the Prime Minister was serious about combating child poverty, why did his colleague in the House state
Oral Questions
yesterday that he did not even have a program to combat child poverty?

speakeroldname: Hon. Benoit Bouchard (Minister of National Health and Welfare):
speakerposition: Minister of National Health and Welfare
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I will not comment on the absence of the member. We appreciate when she is not here because we avoid that kind of statement which is absolutely false.
Yesterday we said that Canadians will never accept poverty for children. We will fight and struggle against it. We budgeted $3 billion last year. However, it is not just a question of money, it is a question of society. Liberals had the same problem when they were in power. We have the problem and we have improved the situation, but children today face a lot of challenges.
However, we will continue to fight. I hope that if the member has good proposals to make to improve the situation, she will write me and tell me exactly what she believes should be done. In the meantime, she should once again recognize that the money we have put in and the programs we have put forward have helped Canadian children in the fight against poverty.

Mr. Speaker, what is false here is the minister's statement that children are better off today than they were 10 years ago. Does he realize that in Canada today, 700,000 children go to food banks? Ten years ago, young people did not go to food banks.
Why did the minister admit in this House yesterday that there was no established policy, when two years ago, his Prime Minister made it clear to the entire international community that his number one priority was the child assistance policy, which is no longer true today?
Hon. Benoit Bouchard (Minister of National Health
and Welfare): It is amazing how the hon. member manages to say at anytime whatever comes into her head, even if it is completely inaccurate. There were always food banks for children, even when the hon. member's party was in power. In every society there have always been children who were helped by volunteer groups. I suggest she ask the World Health Organization and the United Nations Council on Children which stated that the policy developed by this Prime Minister after the children's summit and based on children at risk

Oral Questions
and on child benefits was one of the best in the world. I suggest she do her homework before talking through her hat in this House.

Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Prime Minister. During the recent referendum debate, the Government of Canada spent $350 million to make information available to Canadian people about what they were voting on. During that referendum debate an additional $3 million of taxpayers' money was spent to send out a government propaganda piece in favour of the North American free trade agreement.
In the face of these expenditures, can the Prime Minister tell me whether or not the people of Canada are entitled to the same access on NAFTA? Why is it we are not allowed to spend one penny to advertise that we are having committee hearings in five cities across this country on NAFTA?

Mr. Speaker, I hope the figures used by my hon. friend in future will be more accurate than the one he just used. He has seriously mislead the House and the Canadian people. This government and this Parliament never spent $350 million on information in respect of the last referendum.

Mr. Speaker, if I am to be corrected by the Prime Minister, may I make this request? Is the government willing to spend one-tenth of what it spent on advertising for the referendum to inform the people of this country where hearings are being held?

Mr. Speaker, when my hon. friend ceases using numbers then all of a sudden he becomes more reasonable and his argument is easier to deal with.
Obviously one-tenth of $350 million is one thing, one-tenth of an infinitely more modest figure is another, and I will be happy to refer my hon. friend's request to the chairman of the standing committee.

Mr. Speaker, my question is for the minister of health. Yesterday Campaign 2000 released its report on poverty. I hope by this time the minister has had an opportunity to read it.
This report states that a mother with two children receiving the greatest benefits will get a whole extra 46 cents a day per child with the new child benefit. Will the minister explain to these women exactly what sort of improvements will come into the lives of their children at the rate of 46 cents a day?
Hon. Benoit Bouchard (Minister of National Health
and Welfare): Mr. Speaker, in any benefit package for children, we are trying to determine, first, what we have to do and, second, whom we will target.
The hon. member knows very well that the tax benefit package has been determined to target the low-income earners, those who want to remain in the labour force with an income between $10,000 and $20,000.
Five hundred dollars more per family per year represents a modest amount of money. Mr. Speaker, my supplementary question is for the same minister. The minister always responds to these questions with the same answer that the government has no money.
The government is a system and has an approach to making choices. The government has made choices on how to spend $160 billion a year. The government has decided to spend $24 million promoting its agenda for prosperity.

Forty-three per cent of Canada's haemophiliacs, 800 men, women and children, are HIV positive as a result of receiving tainted blood. Half of those people have AIDS. This is not a partisan issue. It is for that reason that we in the opposition are proposing the following.

The department has been advised that if there is any reason to believe that something happened which would determine that it is a necessity to keep the full confidence of Canadians in the system we have now, I would not hesitate one second. Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Minister of Transport.
Every day we see the disastrous results of the deregulation policies introduced first by the Liberals and continued by the Conservatives. Yesterday as this House knows, the CPR announced its intention to abandon its Atlantic lines east of Sherbrooke, Quebec. This morning on CTV's Canada AM the general manager of that company indicated that this was the beginning of the end of rail competition from Thunder Bay to the Atlantic Ocean.
My question for the Minister of Transport is the same as it was yesterday. Is the minister prepared to give a policy directive to the National Transportation Agency to order it not to accept any applications to abandon any main lines by any railroad anywhere in Canada?

Mr. Speaker, since the hon. member has indicated that it was the same question as yesterday, my answer would have to be the same.
We have put in place a system whereby a railway company that wants to abandon a section of its operation addresses its request to the National Transportation Agency which is an arm's length agency to the government.
This is the process that has been started. It will be examined. Every player, every stakeholder, every group, every person that wishes to question the advisability of this will have the occasion to appear before the NTA and in due course the NTA will render its decision. Madam Speaker, I rise to pay tribute to Anthony Roman, a great Canadian who died unexpectedly on Friday, October 30,. 1992, while recovering from brain surgery.
Anthony Roman was bom January 17, 1936 in Velky-Ruskov, Czechoslovakia. He immigrated to Canada on June 19, 1937.
As a young man, Mr. Roman attended St. Michael's High School in Toronto and later attended the Ontario Agricultural College in Guelph.
Tony Roman's interest in politics was apparent early. He was elected a ward councillor in the township in 1966. He became deputy reeve in 1968, and when the town of Markham was formed in 1971 he was elected its first mayor.
Tony Roman served the people of Markham with distinction for over 20 years. This record of service included being chairman of the Regional Municipality of York in 1984.
Also in 1984 he ran successfully as a member of Parliament for the riding of York North. While sitting as an independent MP in Ottawa, Tony Roman served on the public accounts committee and on the panel of chairmen for legislative bills.

November 18, 1992
Tributes
I believe Tony's first love was being mayor of Markham. Under his leadership and guidance Markham grew from a small village to a prosperous, energetic town of over 150,000 residents.
As Acting Mayor Frank Scarpitti said:
When you thought about Markham you thought about Tony
Roman.
York Region Chairman Eldred King said:
He's made a great contribution to the town of Markham and the
region of York for over 22 years. He will be missed.
In closing, our love and prayers go out to Tony's wife Elsie, sons Michael and Edward, daughters Maria and Paula, and his father George.

Madam Speaker, Anthony Roman was my predecessor as the member of Parliament for York North, and his commitment to those he represented has always been an example for me.
Mr. Roman was a public servant; he devoted his life to serving and helping people. More than almost anything else he loved his town, Markham, and contributed greatly to its growth and advancement. I know that Mr. Roman will be greatly missed by everyone in Markham, in York region, and by those he served with in this place.
His long and esteemed career began in 1966 when he was elected as councillor in the township. Mr. Roman went on to serve as deputy reeve and was elected mayor of Markham in 1971.
He served with distinction in that post until 1984. He was also the regional chair of York region that year. 1984 was also the year Mr. Roman was elected as member of Parliament for York North.
It is a mark of his singular appeal that a man who ran as an independent in 1984 was rewarded by the electorate with its trust. He honoured that trust as a a member of Parliament and devoted himself to defending the interests of his constituents above all else.
In 1988 Mr. Roman returned to municipal politics and once again was elected as mayor of Markham, a position he held until his untimely passing last month. In losing Tony Roman the town of Markham and York region have lost one of their most tireless champions.
On behalf of the leader of the Liberal Party of Canada, our caucus and our party, I would like to offer our most heartfelt sympathies to his wife Elsie, his sons Michael and Edward, his daughters Maria and Paula, and his father George. Our thoughts and prayers are with them.

Madam Speaker, when Tony Roman was elected to the House of Commons to represent the constituency of York North in 1984 he brought with him a wealth of experience from having served for many years at both the regional and municipal levels of government. In the four years of his service in the House of Commons he drew on that experience to bring the concerns of his constituents to this House and to the committees on which he served.
After he chose not to seek re-election to the House of Commons in 1988 he went on to become the mayor of his community and continued to serve in that office until his untimely passing on October 30, 1992.
Tony Roman will be sadly missed by the people of his community and by the people of Canada as a whole.
On behalf of the New Democratic Party, I want to express our sincere condolences to Tony's wife Elsie and to their children Michael, Maria, Paula and Edward.

Madam Speaker, I mourn also for Tony Roman and want to put on the record the fond memories that I have of working with him in his public life and the commitment that he had to the people who elected him to be here.
I think he was one of the least partisan of all of the members of this House, always ready and willing to work and share with us in the interests of serving all of our constituents better. He was a wonderful representative of Markham and he will be missed.
I want also to add that when the story is written one day of the history of liberation of eastern Europe, and particularly the part of it that his family came from, which is Slovakia, that no small part of the work of liberating that part of eastern Europe is to the credit of the Canadian communities of immigrants from those parts of the world.
Mr. Roman was a proud member of one of the families from Slovakia who worked tirelessly for advancing the interests of democracy and the interests of freedom in the part of eastern Europe from which they had come.

I look forward to other Canadians becoming aware of what it is that was done by him in the spirit of opening up freedom and democracy in that part of the world. Madam Speaker, I knew Mr. Roman when he was elected in 1984 and I sat beside him for a while. He was a great man. He was elected as an independent member and, as was said, he was not partisan. Madam Speaker, I am introducing this bill today because of the sad fact in Canada that peace bonds are ineffective as a deterrent to violence, most particularly violence against women.
It is hoped that the proposed amendments to sections 8(10) and 8(11) of the Criminal Code will make peace bonds more effective by sending out a message that offenders will be prosecuted and by compelling justices of the peace to issue peace bonds.
In brief, these amendments would make it incumbent upon the justice of the peace to issue a peace bond in the case where a complainant has demonstrated that her fears are reasonable and, second, classify breaches of the peace by a person bound by a recognizance as indictable offences.
In this age of violence against women, it becomes even more true that justice must not only be done, it must be seen to be done.

Madam Speaker, I have two petitions. The first petition deals with pollution in the Rideau River in my riding and was signed by a number of constituents in Ottawa-Vanier. I would like Parliament to ask the federal government to act as an equal partner with provincial and municipal authorities in implementing an action plan for clean-up and maintenance of the Rideau River.

Madam Speaker, my second petition deals with the Court Challenges Program, which as you know has helped a number of individuals and minority groups to have their constitutional linguistic and equality rights clarified before the courts.
As you know, the program was abolished by the government, and your petitioners strongly urge Parliament to reinstate this program so that Canadians, whatever their income or resources, can bring their cases before the courts and defend their fundamental and linguistic rights.

Madam Speaker, I have a number of petitions to present today.
The first one arises out of the death of a constituent of mine and is related to a theme that has already arisen a couple of times in the House today, that is the issue of violence against women.
The people who have signed this petition call upon Parliament to amend the Criminal Code of Canada to permit the courts to prevent the release of individuals where it is shown that there is a substantial likelihood of further conjugal or family violence being perpetrated.

Madam Speaker, my second petition concerns Bill C-91 and the issue of amending the drug patent laws of Canada.
Routine Proceedings
The petitioners are concerned about the effect of Bill C-91 and its relationship to the North American free trade agreement.
They call upon Parliament not to proceed with Bill C-91 and to repeal Bill C-22, passed in 1987, so that Canadians will have the full benefit of lower priced generic drugs and so that provincial and private drug plans can serve Canadians without being forced to charge higher fees and/or provide less coverage.

Madam Speaker, I have a number of petitions concerning the case of Christine Lamont and David Spencer, who are Canadians imprisoned in Brazil. In the judgment of many Canadians they should now be back in Canada but for the cruelty of the minister of external affairs who refuses to request their expulsion, thereby leaves them in prison in Brazil where riots and massacres take place and where they are in imminent danger.
I present these petitions calling upon Parliament to urge the Secretary of State for External Affairs to request the Government of Brazil to expel Christine Lamont and David Spencer and return them to Canada.

They want to stress that we have many Manitobans who have contributed to Manitoba and to its airline industry. Finally they stress that any change would cost a great deal of money to everyone. They oppose this change and they want to make sure that it is prevented. I support this petition.

Madam Speaker, I wish to table a petition signed by residents of Lebel-sur-Quevillon in Abitibi, which says that films on television that show scenes of violence are dangerous and cannot be tolerated because they act as an incentive to further violence.

November 18, 1992

They have collected thousands of names in support of a petition that asks the government to ensure that the Canadian Constitution will contain the five basic principles of medicare, that the federal government will reaffirm its cost-sharing responsibility with the provinces for health care and that the federal government will set up a national monitoring agency to enforce federal-provincial health care programs.

Madam Speaker, pursuant to Standing Order 36 I present the Mackenzie Valley highway petition which states that whereas the Canadian government announced the commencement of the Mackenzie Valley highway in 1972 and construction was started on this important transportation link to the north; and whereas the economic need for a highway system has never been greater than it is today, the federal government has transferred responsibility for northern road construction but not the funding to the government of the Northwest Territories.
Therefore we request that the federal and territorial governments accept their joint responsibilities to the residents of the Mackenzie Valley corridor and commence discussions now to prepare a phased implementation plan for completion of the highway to Fort Norman, Norman Wells, Fort Good Hope and further north to tie in with the existing highway south of Inuvik.
Furthermore, we recommend that these discussions take place with the involvement of northerners and include a construction timetable for completion.
This is presented on behalf of 150 residents of the Sahtu region.

Madam Speaker, pursuant to Standing Order 36 I have the honour to present four petitions. They are all different but all concerned with Bill C-86.
The first petition is signed by 60 persons from Toronto who are concerned with recent amendments to the immigration bill, Bill C-86. In particular, they strongly oppose the restrictions and delay that parents will face when seeking to join their sons and daughters in Canada.

I have a second petition with 126 names of Canadians who are concerned with many of the proposed amendments to the Immigration Act and Bill C-86. They particularly oppose the provisions that allow decisions to be made retroactively on the ground that it would cause many individuals and families who have already relied upon an earlier decision to be affected in a serious manner.
They urge Parliament to urge the government to withdraw these amendments.

Madam Speaker, my third petition is from 133 Canadians who point out that the refugee board at present is not allowed to review decisions even when it is apparent that a mistake may have been made, evidence that was missing is now available, or that the situation has turned.
This is in spite of the fact that the United Nations minimum guarantee for refugee status determination requires an appeal on the merits.
Therefore the undersigned petitioners humbly pray and call upon Parliament to enact legislation which would provide a meaningful appeal on the merits for refugee claimants whose cases are rejected such that they have appeal rights comparable with everyone else in Canada.

speechtext:
Madam Speaker, I rise under Standing Order 52 to request an emergency debate on the state of Canada's transportation industry. I request this debate for a number of reasons, most of which are being played out on the front pages of most of our newspapers at this very moment. One of course is the story we have all been following very closely in the past number of weeks which involves all Canadians. That is the crisis in the airline industry which involves not only PWA and Canadian Airlines, but also Air Canada.
I think it is incumbent upon us as members of Parliament to stand up here in Parliament and debate this issue and debate it very, very soon.
In particular, as an Atlantic Canadian, the news yesterday in Atlantic Canada with regard to transportation was not particularly good. We have a crisis looming there as well since CP Rail made known its intention to abandon or seek abandonment of all its rail lines in Atlantic Canada.
I do not think I have to go on any further. It is being suggested by the other side of the House that I save my speech for the debate. Madam Speaker, I want to impress upon you the importance of it because in a country as large as Canada I think the 27 million Canadians who are watching us from time to time should be aware of exactly what is happening out there and it is incumbent upon us as members of Parliament to put that message out.
The decision has been made by CP Rail to abandon the rail lines in eastern Canada. That is an entire region of Canada that is going to be abandoned by a major corporation that has been mandated and has the respon-
November 18, 1992
