Madam Speaker, these motions have been grouped: Motion No. 3 dealing with family members: Motion No. 5 dealing with visitors' visas; Motion No. 70 with residency requirements; and Motion No. 74 which deals with the refund of the fee. Let me first deal with family members and what is specifically meant by this clause.
When officials and senior immigration officers are processing an application they can assess all members of a family when deciding on the immigration application of one member of that family. It is our position that the application should only be assessed on the merits of that particular person who is making an application to come to Canada, along with those members of his family who will accompany the applicant to Canada.

Government Orders
Unless this procedure is followed it is a fundamental denial of procedural fairness if some person is being tried, being judged or is having an adjudication made on his or her behalf based on the actions of perhaps another family member.
When we talk about family members under the extended meaning of that phrase it embraces a whole class of people: spouses, fiances, unmarried children of any age, a child under 13, or parents of any age, grandparents who are over 60, orphan brothers and sisters, nephews, nieces or grandchildren. It goes on and on.
The purpose of this amendment dealing with family members is to ensure that the application and consideration should only be given to that person who is applying for status along with those dependants or those people he will be bringing with him at the time of his application.
There is a proverb that we never had any opportunity to pick our family members, in his wisdom the good Lord having deprived us of that right, but he allowed us to choose our own friends. This particular section reminds me of that. It reminds this side that people who are making an application to come to this country are being jeopardized by certain acts of members of a truly large and extended family.
A hypothetical situation could result in valued members, whom we would welcome with open arms into our country as the very type of people this country wants and whose skills we need, being denied admittance because after an investigation of the extended family members one may have done something that is contrary to certain sections of the act. Although that person is not making any representation to become a Canadian citizen the application of that whole family is denied because of the acts of that one person at whatever time in that person's history.
We feel that matter should be clarified and that procedural fairness should be applied just to those people making application and to those who are intending to come to Canada with the original applicant.
With respect to visitors' visas, we are proposing a more definitive way for those folks who are working the immigration offices throughout the world to be able to
make a more definitive answer with respect to visitors' visas.
We all know, those of us who work in our constituency offices, that if there is an immigration matter that comes before us it more often concerns a refusal of a visitor's permit to Canada. When there is an intervention by a member of Parliament questioning the wisdom of not granting a visitor's permit I would say that on 99.9 per cent of the occasions that this happens the visitor's permit is granted.
What we are trying to do with Motion No. 5 is eliminate some of the abuses that we have been finding recently in the foreign offices throughout the world, some of which we have heard of just recently. The amendment deals with the further presumption that when a person makes a statement under oath to a department official in our embassies that there is a fundamental rule in law of a presumption of innocence.
What we should be doing in this instance is presuming that the person who comes to our offices to be granted a visitor's visa should be presumed to have told the truth about everything in that application. At this particular period of time there is a presumption that perhaps what is being stated to a visa officer is not true.
What we are really doing in this motion is enforcing the concept which we all hold very dear in the system of laws that we have in this country, which is the presumption that the person who is making those statements is making the proper statements.
Therefore, we recommend that particular change with respect to the additions of the immigration officer being put into the position-and the operative words in the section that we propose are "shall not refuse", providing certain conditions in that application are adhered to. Once those conditions are adhered to it should only be a matter of procedure that the visitors' visa be granted to those people planning to visit relatives or friends in Canada.
Motion No. 70 concerns the residency requirement. It says that at the time of issuing an immigrant visa the period of time allocated to live in certain communities within our country should be limited to a two-year period.

I must confess that I have some doubts about this particular section. I am absolutely sure that this is one of the first sections of this proposed act that will be tested in the courts, right up to the Supreme Court of Canada, if it should pass. If a person becomes a landed immigrant and eventually becomes a citizen of this country and is forced to stay in a certain area, it infringes on the Charter of Rights and Freedoms.
If I am correct, what we are trying to do in legislation such as we have before us today is prevent the application and the costly processes with regard to legislation this House passes and which places a tremendous burden on Canadian citizens to have their matters tested in the courts. It is the duty of all of us who have anything to do with the wording of legislation to provide the proper legislation to prevent the necessity for this particular section to be tested in the courts for interpretation.
This is the highest court in the land. We should be very precise in the wording we use and very precise with what we are asking people to do through legislation such as this so that it does not interfere with the Charter of Rights and Freedoms of Canada.
I would suspect that this is a matter that would be tested in the courts in very short order if this motion is not adhered to.
I might also add that on the residency requirement the Senate committee voted unanimously that this amendment, requiring a period not exceeding two years, be accepted. We propose that amendment with Motion No. 70.
Motion No. 74 concerns the refund of immigration fees. The bill as it reads now anticipates a retroactive processing charge of immigrant applications up to the point of either a suspension or a cancellation by the minister. Our amendment is again based on procedural fairness. The change that we are proposing in this particular motion is that once an application is accepted by a responsible official of the Government of Canada if that application at any time is thwarted because of procedural requirements or whatever reason, which should have been discovered at the time of acceptance of that application, then any funds paid by the person making the application should be refunded.
Government Orders
I believe the cost now is about $350. Tb some members of this House $350 is not a great amount of money. However, for people of Third World countries $350 is a large amount of money. That represents perhaps their total life savings, which they have given for the opportunity to come to Canada.
We would suggest once an application is accepted and the fee is paid that if there is a breakdown in the process or a suspension of the process that money be returned to the applicant.
Those are the points we want to make. We impress upon the government that they are very valid points. In some instances they will stop court proceedings. There is then a certain procedural fairness that applies to all Canadians by adhering to the Charter of Rights and Freedoms of our country. It would make good sense if all sides accepted those recommendations.

Madam Speaker, I am delighted to speak to these amendments.
First, I would like to congratulate my colleague for Thunder Bay-Nipigon for his excellent work on behalf of our caucus on the many amendments that have been proposed. I would also like to remind the House that the bill we are discussing today consists of some 113 pages, 128 clauses, the most extensive amendments in the history of the Immigration Act in Canada.
We should give due care and time to consider the amendments that we have proposed today. With respect to Motion No. 3 respecting family members, I would like to indicate that I strongly underscore the point made earlier by my colleague.
Indeed, we should continue to respect the individuality of citizens wherever they are. When they come and apply to Canada to be potential immigrants, the difficulties of one may not be used to penalize the potential benefits of others that come to our country.
We have seen cases of that. I have seen actual cases of a family member left behind. Now they are trying to continue to so-call extend the investigation of the remaining family member. Therefore, those who have arrived are filled with fear and trepidation. Will they be sent back if this one additional member of their family is unable to be allowed in under our current regulations?

November 18, 1992
Government Orders
I would like to underscore the fact that yes, we must evaluate those who have applied. Consider them on the basis of their reasons and intentions and the wishes of those of the same family who elect for whatever reason not to be included in that application must be respected. I have wondered if without that amendment being adopted we can in fact prevent really large families from coming to Canada under the guise that one family member is not admissible. That is not in keeping with the standards of the United Nations.
On the second point, Motion No. 5, regarding the visitor's visa, indeed we must underscore that the presumption of goodwill must be in favour of the applicant. We are proud of ourselves as a nation. We try to promote tourism to Canada. What better tool for tourism to say yes, Canada welcomes visitors from any land. Visitors applying to visit the country should not be quizzed as though they were already on trial, as though they were committing an offence. It is really a disgrace if we let the impression continue that in order to enter Canada you must pass a critical test, almost like a judicial trial.
We have to give the presumption of favourable consideration to the visitor applicants, moreover I submit, particularly when relatives of the potential visitor applicants are citizens of Canada. Can you imagine a Canadian citizen deprived of the benefit of a visit from his or her relatives from their country of birth?
It would be most painful, particularly when those visits are to join families in Canada in a special celebration such as a wedding anniversary. A golden anniversary is a classic example. Sometimes even when visiting family members whose relatives are near death in a hospital they encounter problems.
I submit that we should give good guidelines to our immigration officials so that they too will be placed in an easier position to evaluate. Let us remove from them as well the heavy burden of making the judgment as though the visitors are to violate the immigration law and the law of the country.
On the motion submitted by my colleague for Scarborough-Rouge River, I would like to indicate that this suggestion on the part of my colleague is really an attempt, almost a last desperate attempt, to find an additional tool with which we can allow legitimate visitors to enter the country.
If one were to ask me, we ought not to come to the requirement of a surety or a bond, but my colleague in trying to find a solution and give that extra ounce of assurance has come up creatively with this proposal which I support. I would like to indicate that perhaps this type of requirement would not be the routine requirement in the future.
On the issue of Motion No. 70 about the residency requirement, like my colleague from Thunder Bay I am seized by a nagging fear that this requirement may be contrary to section 6, paragraph 2, of the Charter of Rights and Freedoms, lliis section guarantees the mobility of any Canadian citizen, including landed Canadian immigrants. By reducing it to a two-year requirement, it could be construed perhaps as a part of a work contract. I am sure prospective immigrants would not mind that kind of designation to a designated place. I hope the courts would take a reasonable look at that.
I was once an immigrant. I entered the country in 1968. When I entered the city of Winnipeg in Manitoba, I did not think that I was only entering Winnipeg, although I knew where I was going geographically. I knew I was becoming a Canadian immigrant and in the future a Canadian citizen, which I did some three or four years later, in 1972.
The intention of the immigrant to be a Canadian should be looked upon with the kind of broad view that truly it is more than a mere statement of wanting to be a Canadian. There is inherent in that the rights that accrue to being a Canadian immigrant and in the future a Canadian citizen. Those rights are entrenched in the Citizenship Act and also in the Immigration Act.
On that basis, I definitely support a limitation of the residency requirement to at most two years in the belief that this will facilitate the entry of some of the immigrants in areas where their expertise and skills are needed most during a certain period of time.

I want to thank you for reading through the amendment which was a little long but it was either you, Madam Speaker, or me who was going to read it.
In looking at this amendment, I want to ask members to put on somebody else's shoes here. I want them to put on the shoes of a Canadian who has a mother, father, brother, sister, son or daughter who is not a Canadian citizen and who resides in another country.

I want members to do that and then plan a visit of their family member, let us say their father or the mother. Plan a reunion, go through all of the planning, set aside the funds, get the family organized here, get the family organized there, purchase the airline ticket, which for overseas travel could be $1,000 or $2,000. Maybe it is the father and the mother. Then I want the members to think about their father and mother lining up at a foreign embassy or a high commission for a few hours, starting maybe at 5 a.m. or 6 a.m. and then being told to go away and get some more paperwork. Go and get a letter from your son or daughter in Canada. Do something else, we are missing a piece of paper. Come back next week. Bring them back next week, go through the process again, and then have the Canadian official decide no. In that context let us not have the Canadian official give any reason for the rejection of the application. Let us take the mother and father in that country and take them back to their home and have them write or telephone the son or daughter in Canada and say: "We were turned down. We do not know why".
I want members to put those shoes on and try to figure out why it is so many close relatives of Canadians living in countries abroad are turned down for visits. I know it is a large number because my constituents come to me with these problems. Maybe it does not happen in a lot of cities and towns across Canada, but it does happen in the riding that I represent. I know it happens in all of the ridings around my riding in metropolitan Toronto, and is probably a similar circumstance in Vancouver, Montreal and in other larger cities in Canada. This is a problem.
I want members to wear those shoes and I want the members to try to think of a way to overcome the problem. To date, we have not.
The law says now that the burden of showing entitlement to a visitor's visa is on the applicant, not on anybody else. If the applicant simply fails to convince the visa officer that he or she is bona fide and that he or she will comply with the terms of the visa, simply failing to convince is sufficient. The visa officer does not have to decide that person is a liar or will not comply. The visa
Government Orders
officer simply has to reach a conclusion that the applicant has failed to convince.
There are a lot of reasons why these kinds of applicants could fail to convince. For example, they may not speak English very well. This happens all the time. They cannot convey. They are bona fides. They cannot convey all the nuances that have to be conveyed in trying to convince a visa officer that they are bona fide. I want members to think about that.
I and all members recognize that there are abuses. There have been abuses of the visitor visas and it still goes on now, originating from many countries. The current system penalizes the close relatives of Canadians, Canadian citizens. Canadians say: "Why can my mother, father, brother, sister, son and daughter not visit?" I do not have an answer for them.
This amendment which I have moved would permit a Canadian to put forward a surety or form of guarantee to the immigration deputy minister in the same type of surety vehicle that exists now for people who are released from custody by immigration officials. This would assist the visa officer if that surety was in existence and put forward by the Canadian in relation to the proposed visit of the mother, father, brother, sister, son or daughter. The visa officer would then know that there was a Canadian at the other end because sometimes they do not know that. They would know there was a Canadian who had put forth an undertaking that manifested or articulated the good faith of the Canadian in relation to the visit.
Some have suggested that there could be a charter problem here, but I do not understand that. I do not understand it because we already use sureties under the Immigration Act. Already visa officers abroad will consider letters from the Canadian relative alleging good faith or offering good faith and undertakings of financial support of the proposed visitor. As it so often happens with family visitors who do not often come with a lot of money, they stay with the relative here.
That is what my amendment proposes. My amendment does not change any of the existing criteria for visitor visas. None of those criteria are changed. All that it does is permit the addition of one new element, the surety

November 18, 1992
Government Orders
representing the good faith of the Canadian in the invitation of the visitor who is a close family member.
I say to members here and I say to the members opposite recalling that this very subject was a matter which was considered as part of Private Members' Business in this House about a year ago. I say to them that it is important. I say that the Department of Immigration has not fairly and adequately considered this as a problem for reasons which I do not know. I certainly represent Canadians who know that it is a problem. The government has not responded. I say to it: Please, do not miss this opportunity to address this very particular and very real problem.

Madam Speaker, I rise particularly to speak to Motion No. 7 which stands in my name. Since it is a very simple motion I will have to explain what it is.
On page 16 of the bill, section 10.2(1) states:
An immigrant who makes an application in Canada for landing may
apply on behalf of that person and every dependant in Canada.
The point of my amendment is to strike out the words "in Canada" and replace them with the words "of that person" so that immigrant would be able to apply on behalf of himself or herself and every dependant of that person.
If a family is coming here and perhaps one teen-age dependant remains to study in the old country or for some reason wishes to stay temporarily but follow, it would seem to me very unfortunate if that person were not able to have an application for landing processed along with the parents and any other brothers and sisters.
It would be doubly unfortunate if the sponsorship procedure, which has now slowed down considerably through the mail-in arrangements at least around Toronto or the general crowding caused that 17 or 18 year old to be delayed in the working out of his application until he or she passed the age of 19. In that case he or she would no longer be a family member within the meaning of this act. He or she would have to apply as an independent immigrant and might have great difficulty doing that or at least have an unexpected delay.
It seems to me to be reasonable to allow the general immigrant family the same procedure as this bill allows to a person who has been found in Canada to be a
refugee and is therefore entitled to apply for the landing of his whole family, which is almost always outside the country, at the same time as he or she applies for his landing.
I applaud the decision of the government to make that provision for the refugee because we have had great distress of thousands and thousands of people in refugee families who have been separated. I am not suggesting that there is likely to be the same amount of trouble in the same number of people in the non-refugee cases. In fact, landing within Canada, apart from refugees, is the exception rather than the rule. It will not happen very often and it has not happened very often. The rule is landing from outside Canada where this question does not apply.
I ask the members opposite to consider for their own constituents as well as for everybody elses' constituents the convenience, where it is asked, of making the application for all the dependants, including any who are overseas at the time of application in the case where a person is making application from within Canada himself or herself. It seems to me that it would be just as efficient from the point of view of the department and far more satisfactory from the point of view of that dependant and of the family.
While I am on this, I wish to comment on these other motions that are before us in this group.
Motion No. 3 would change the wording in clause 4 to "any or all accompanying dependants". It makes much more sense not to force people, if they do not wish it, to make an application for dependants overseas. For the reasons that have been given already, it should be left to the choice of the family concerned. It may be necessary to make certain assurances that the choice will not be reneged upon in legal form. However, if it is reneged upon, it should only be with the minister's permission or something like that. It seems to me quite unnecessary to restrict the family from that freedom of movement.
We should all be strongly in sympathy with Motions Nos. 5 and 6. I do not imagine there is any member of Parliament who has not been genuinely distressed at the difficulty that some constituents have in getting a visitors' visa. We heard the argument previously that if anything is written into the law then it becomes a matter of right that people can demand and even, perhaps, a subject of litigation. This is true.
November 18, 1992

In my experience the large number of applications for a family visitor that are delayed and even the large number that are finally refused as well as delayed is out of proportion to the danger of abuse in the other direction. I think the present abuse is to the disadvantage of the family and not really to the advantage of the department.
I wish to speak also on Motion No. 70. This new system of requiring some immigrants-we are told it will only be a handful-to live in certain areas is unnecessary. It will be entirely at the discretion of the government. Some immigrants will be told they have to go to Podunk and work at such and such an occupation. At present there is no time limit given.
It was suggested that it might end at three years when the person becomes a citizen and, therefore, can claim charter rights. I am not clear on that. If charter rights do not apply when the person is a permanent resident, I am not sure they apply when the person is a citizen. Alternatively, if a citizen could complain against that, then why not a permanent resident under the same charter?
I think a time limit is needed and it should be two years rather than three years. Things are mobile enough in Canada that circumstances change. I know that what was once considered mandatory conditions have now been softened so that they are not mandatory conditions and people can apply to have them changed if employment or living arrangements fail or something of that nature.
It would reduce the unnecessary burden of applications if the requirement to live in a certain area was limited to two years. Not all permanent residents wish to proceed or do proceed to citizenship at three years. Some people have stayed here for many years for reasons satisfactory to themselves and presumably of no harm to anybody else. I would not want them then to be held by this.
On Motion No. 74, where an immigrant has paid fees for a visa application, the fees so incurred shall be reimbursed to the immigrant if the application is refused or is not considered as a result of retroactive regulations.
It is quite true that the present fees-and they probably are not likely to go down, they are more likely to go up-can be a serious burden, especially on a family of several members from Third World countries, or even from many European countries. With the uncertainty
Government Orders
that the application could be cancelled part way through by a retroactive decision and that the fees would have to be paid all over again, or the plan given up entirely even in future years seems to me a way of keeping immigrants out of Canada.
If that is not the intent of the government, I would hope that it would agree to this amendment. I know the government has emphasized the wish to have good immigrants, and I think we want immigrants to be attracted by reasonable government with a reasonable law such as this amendment proposes.

Madam Speaker, I want to thank my colleagues for the comments they have made.
A number of points were made that will be extremely useful and will ensure that we have a fair, common sense, sensitive, orderly and humanitarian policy on immigration.
Most of us are coming at this from the basic principle that immigrants can and do enrich our country in many ways. We have in this House a colleague who has come from another country and has contributed a great deal to Canada.
In my own riding, we have a week called Kermes Week when we celebrate the achievements of the Belgian community. We have Folklorama as well where we have 50 various kiosks celebrating the various contributions of Canadians from some 50 different countries.
One of the points that I want to stress very strongly is that we have a number of what one could call nightmare situations or horror stories. I want to share with the House one case with which I am dealing currently.
A Canadian citizen whose widowed mother lives in Bangladesh has been waiting for two years and eight months and has not yet received even an interview. Still ahead of her are a background investigation and medicals. I find this deplorable, unnecessary and shocking. This mother is virtually by herself and almost three years later has still not been responded to.
In another case, a citizen in my constituency found out that members of his family in Vietnam had left on fragile boats and had reached Hong Kong. They could be repatriated to Vietnam at any time and there are serious questions which have been raised about the fate that awaits them on their return.

November 18, 1992
Government Orders
Perhaps the one issue-some of my colleagues have spoken about it-that enrages Canadian citizens most are those situations where parents or relatives want to come and visit them, but are unable to do so. Imagine the silliness of it all. We have mothers and fathers, brothers and sisters and sometimes spouses who will go to a point in the United States that is close to Canada and that individual who is here with a visa, or he may be a Canadian citizen, will go out of the country in order to visit those relatives or friends.
I cannot imagine this, particularly when we want to promote our country. We want to make sure that people come here rather than the United States. We want them to visit with their relatives at their home, to be able to share with them their new lives.
I will give you three quick situations. In one instance, a young woman is studying at the University of Manitoba and her husband is studying in Australia. Her husband wants to come to Winnipeg to visit his wife and there is the likelihood that he may want to stay here. I understand that, but at the same time once we have had a written commitment from both parties, it seems to me that we ought to take a chance. The reunion of those two people has been prevented.
In another instance, a gentleman who is a Canadian citizen wanted his mother-in-law to come to his wedding. Again, I understand that there may have been the possibility that the person from another country wanted to come and stay and they were prepared to make written commitments and yet that particular person who wanted to come to Canada for that wedding was unable to do so.
Finally my third example is of a woman who had not seen her parents for some time, whose parents were denied entry into Canada, even though she was a Canadian citizen. She had to fly out of the country to see her mother and father. I find that shocking and really unnecessary. This is one issue that must be dealt with.
I just want to make some very quick comments about the other amendments here. Clearly we need to deal with the applicant. Whatever the other members of the family do, in whatever way family is defined, should not
have an impact upon the applicant's desire to come into the country.
I think we have to respect the fundamental principle of Canadian law as well that whatever is declared is true unless proven to be untrue. Otherwise, we apply two different standards.
I want to question the government-I say this in a very positive kind of way-about the residency requirements. Everyone tells me that it will not hold up in court. I wonder whether or not the government has checked this out. Is the government in fact proceeding here, yet it is for naught because it will not in fact go through?
Finally, with respect to immigration fees, I would like us to consider just how much $350 is today in Canadian money and how much this really represents to those who are very often in extremely difficult poverty-stricken situations. We really need to examine that.
We need to take very seriously those criticisms, those points that are being raised by organizations, including churches, that are committed to making sure that we have an orderly, sensitive and humanitarian approach to immigration in this country.

Madam Speaker, I am delighted to follow my other colleagues in speaking on the report stage of this bill. I am sad, too, that we are still having this kind of debate with regard to immigration.
I look around among my own colleagues in the House this afternoon. I see names that are French, English, Italian, Hungarian, Filipino, Irish, Jewish or whatever in one portion of this House. We are all immigrants. The fact that some of us came recently while some of us had families that came a century or more ago is merely a question of timing.
The second thing that amazes me about the fact that we are still having this debate and dealing with a bill that is essentially flawed, is the size of this enormous country with its enormous potential and with its need for a larger population. How many of us in how many parts of the country and on how many occasions have used the image of our tiny population strung out across the bottom part of the country? How many of us have gone to northern Canada, to the vast empty reaches of this country, to see what could be done if only we had more people? How much could be done if only we opened our doors
November 18, 1992

generously the way the doors were open certainly in the 17th, 18th and 19th centuries when my ancestors came here?
I hear my hon. friend from Alberta over there making comments about when the Liberals were in power. I guess what some of the people on the government side do not understand is that we in the Liberal Party learn from our mistakes. It might be something the hon. member might want to think on if indeed the process is possible. The hon. member from Newfoundland might want to think too, but I will deal with him in a minute.
One of the amendments that I want to talk about in particular has to do with family members and the questions that this bill raises. The bill provides that the government can assess all members of a family when it is deciding on the immigration application of one member of that family. That is nothing more and nothing less than guilt by association. There is a real problem.
It is true that some of us in this House subscribe to the theory of being one's brother's or one's sister's keeper, but this is going a little too far. Obviously in this modem age, and particularly in an age when families are split up and far away from each other even within one particular country, it is utterly insane to decide whether or not Mr. Jones should be accepted on the basis of whether or not his brother is an acceptable candidate. It goes against the rales of natural justice and it goes against those principles that we hold dear in our own Charter of Rights and Freedoms. I think it is utterly appalling that we are even contemplating something of this nature.
Look at the question of Canada and its immigration policy particularly in the world that we are facing today. Look at what is happening in eastern Europe. Look at what is happening in Africa in Somalia. We see the carnage in Yugoslavia and we know that there are those who are refugees in the truest sense of the word. They have no homes to go to any longer because their homes have been destroyed. They are the victims of civil war and insurrection based on ethnic cleansing or on religious bigotry.
We look at this immense country. We look at this blessed country. We look at each one of us who came ourselves or whose ancestors came here to escape
Government Orders
something similar in another country to make a better life.
The parliamentarians and legislators of this country say: "Too bad for you. It is too late for you. I have my share. I am here but the rest of you can stay outside the door". How can we? How dare we? We did that, tragically, in times past in this country and all of us bear a portion of our national guilt for that. I do not want future Canadians to bear the same kind of guilt especially when a larger population is something we so desperately need.
Before I came up here on Monday, I was fortunate enough to be present at a YWCA breakfast where they awarded the peace medal to one of my constituents, Dr. Joni Guptill, who has been very active with Doctors Without Borders Medecins sans frontieres in Africa and in Yugoslavia. Dr. Guptill herself spoke about the conditions in those countries. Peter Dalglish is the executive director of Street Kids International, an international foundation based in Toronto that looks after street children. He is a man who is known to many of us on this side of the House at least. He spoke at the same time as Dr. Guptill about the need for Canada to be generous.
The amendments we are bringing forward in this group and in other groups of amendments today are an attempt to make us more generous. We are known world-wide to be among the luckiest citizens on the face of the earth. Because we have so much, are so lucky and live in this incredibly wonderful country, we should be able to share this with others.
It is incumbent upon us to be generous. It is incumbent upon us to show that the legislation that we have dealing with immigration is open and forward looking and welcoming to those people in the world who we can use. The myths have been debunked. Immigrants are not a drain on the public purse. Immigrants do not create difficulties and problems to any extent in the manner that some already arrived and long-term Canadian citizens do. Immigrants are a blessing to a country.
Most important, each one of us has an absolute duty to remember from whence we came. We must not be smug and self-satisfied. We must know that the life-blood of our country and its future will be immigration. We forget this at our peril.

Madam Speaker, I would like to go back to a more specific issue that my friend for Thunder Bay-Nipigon was dealing with before. That is the issue of the visitor's visa and the very discretionary way in which visa officers in our embassies and high commissions deal with that.
I can give a number of examples of problems that I have experienced in my constituency office with families. They tried to bring family members from their homeland overseas to Canada and have had the experience of seeing them rejected in a very arbitrary way by visa officers overseas.
Many of these people are long-time citizens of my constituency who are productive and contributing members of Canadian society. These people are respected in their community, the province and across the country. They have been deprived of the right of contact with family members overseas because visa officers in our high commissions and embassies act in a very arbitrary way.
In many cases these potential visitors are even denied the right to make a written application to come to Canada as a visitor. Let me give you some examples. I had a constituent who is in the import and export business. One of his business partners is a citizen of the Philippines. She is between 25 and 35. The minute she went to talk to the Canadian immigration officials in the Philippines, they decided at first sight that she was an unsuitable visitor to Canada.
The reason for that is that some visa officers overseas have decided that women from certain countries who are of marriageable age would probably violate their visa requirements by trying to marry a Canadian and then apply for landed status in Canada. This woman was denied the right to even apply for a permit.
My constituent called me and asked me to write a letter of recommendation outlining the fact that this woman had been to Canada before on a 60-day visitor's visa and had done her business in Canada. She had travelled around to look at markets and at potential products to market in the Philippines. She had actually gone back before her visa had expired and was, in fact, an exemplary visitor to Canada.
Yet, this woman was rejected on sight. She was not even permitted to make a written application for a visa.
She was simply rejected on sight. I think the immigration officer made a judgment that because she was of marriageable age that through his determination she was not entitled and was not a suitable visitor to Canada.
That has happened on a number of occasions. I know two young women from Chile who attempted to apply to visit Canada. At first, they were reluctant even to approach the Canadian embassy in Chile. They had heard from previous applicants that women of their age, determined by the visa officer to be of marriageable age, are not suitable visitors to Canada because they are likely to attempt to marry a Canadian male and then apply to stay in the country.
I point out that these women are not permitted to make applications. They are simply denied the right to come to Canada on sight because of a discriminatory choice that visa officers made about these women based on their marriageable age or entitlement to be married.
My concern is that the process used now is extremely arbitrary and open to those kinds of discriminatory choices. There has to be something written in legislation which first allows a person who applies for a visitor's visa to be able to make a written application and to outline their suitability to be a visitor to Canada. If they are denied, they should have the right to the reasons for that denial, reasons for the statement made by the visa officer that they are not a suitable visitor, and there should be a process to allow them to appeal.
My concern right now is that many of these people get their family members in Canada to go to their members of Parliament for a letter of recommendation outlining the family's residence in Canada, the fact that they are good citizens, and the fact that this person overseas- whom you do not know and only have the family's word for it-is unlikely to violate the conditions of the visa and is unlikely to stay in Canada at the point the visa expires.
As I have said, my concern is that the process is arbitrary and by requiring people to visit their member of Parliament to get a letter of recommendation it is also politicizing the process so those visitors from overseas get the impression that in Canada the right to visit this country is a right that is handed out by politicians in local communities. I do not think that is the impression we would like to convey to the visitors from overseas.
November 18, 1992

I think the process should be fair and non-discriminatory. It should be conducted in such a way that we allow Canadian citizens who at one time emigrated from other countries to have free contact with family members and friends from their homeland. I think they are being treated unfairly because of the arbitrary nature of the process as we currently have it under the act.
Finally, I would like to outline another case from the Philippines. Two of my constituents, a husband and wife, invited the wife's mother over to visit. They had not seen the wife's mother for many years. She was getting old, so they invited her to Canada to visit. She wanted to bring along her son because she did not feel she could make that journey. It is a long journey from the Philippines to western Canada. She did not feel she could make the journey alone. She might get sick or lost and she did not have the same kind of facility with the language that her daughter and son-in-law in Canada had. She wanted her son to accompany her.
Strangely enough, the visa officer accepted the visa of the mother and rejected the visa of the son because even though he was fully employed in the Philippines working for a telecommunications company, even though he had family in the Philippines that he was going to be leaving behind in order to come on this visit with his mother, even though he had a home and a job, all of those things, it was felt that as his pay with the telecommunications company in the Philippines was low he was likely to stay in Canada and try to apply for a job in Canada where his skills are paid for at a much higher rate by telecommunications companies.
What an arbitrary way to make these decisions. So the son was rejected and because the mother could not travel without accompaniment, she ended up not being able to visit her daughter as well. Again they came to me and applied to me as a member of Parliament to write a letter of recommendation as to the good name and reputation of my constituents living in Port Albemi.
The process should not be as arbitrary as it is and it should not be politicized the way visa officers in embassies overseas are forcing it to be. There should be a process laid down where family members of Canadians who are resident overseas and who want to visit Canada should have the right to make a written application for a
Government Orders
visa. That visa should be processed according to certain criteria that those applicants are aware of.
If they are rejected there should be good reasons made for rejecting them and there should also be a process available to them to appeal. At that point during the appeal process then possibly the member of Parliament or other people willing to make recommendations should be involved.
I am concerned that what is happening here is that Canadians who have come from overseas are being denied the right of contact with their families as a result of arbitrary decisions being made in visa, embassy and high commission offices overseas. I hope that the amendments to this legislation will correct that kind of discriminatory behaviour and make it possible for Canadians to have those kinds of family contacts and visits from overseas.

Madam Speaker, I do not think there is any bill that touches more the expression of what this wonderful country of Canada is really all about: the openness, the respect for difference, and the wish of people around the world to come and either establish themselves here or visit family who are here, or perhaps just visit and see what this whole country is all about. We certainly raised the vision and the visibility of our country over the last couple of months. Nonetheless, we still have lots of people who care to join our shores who recognize the uniqueness of the diversity that is Canada when that diversity includes its culture along with its geography and its language.
We are dealing with specific amendments in this report stage to this extraordinarily complex bill. When I looked at this bill I could only say to my two colleagues, the member for Notre-Dame-de-Grace and the member for Thunder Bay-Nipigon, that they really had to have a tremendous amount of courage and enthusiasm to face a bill of this size in the very short time this government gave them to address the major concerns that are in this bill. Also, over the summer break while the rest of the members of this House perhaps were having some holidays and working in their ridings, these members had to sit and hear witnesses-I am glad at least we allowed witnesses to appear-and go through this enormous bill.

Government Orders
I have forgotten how many pages it is. Somewhere I had the number of pages because I was quite fascinated. We are talking about a bill with 128 sections and 113 pages. It is quite an extensive bill.
The amendments we are addressing today in this report stage start with the questions brought forward by my colleagues, the member for Notre-Dame-de-Grace and the member from Thunder Bay, with respect to the matter of a visa. From my experience as a member, I can tell you that I have had so many visa refusals it is becoming almost an embarrassment. It would seem to be that there are more refusals coming from countries like Sri Lanka, India, Bangladesh, Russia. There is something wrong with the extent of what would seem to me to be countries which seem to be suffering more than other countries in terms of the receipt of a no on a request for a family visit or a visa.
I had one case that I dealt with today with our consulate and our consul general in New York. It was with a great degree of frustration that I spoke with our officers there. I must say that I was quite impressed with the quality of the service I received and I particularly noted Mr. John Baker who was very helpful and seemingly very thoughtful.
Nonetheless, he had some misinformation on the documents which he was reviewing. I am not suggesting that it was done in any kind of a duplicitous way, but I am saying that it was very difficult to try to resolve the problem of a Sikh family in my riding who were joyfully celebrating the marriage of their daughter, who just graduated as a doctor, to a doctor colleague. The wedding was taking place in New York. This gentleman, who is a substantial member of our community and well respected, had invited his brother and his brother's family to come to the wedding.
Only the brother intended to come and went to our offices in New Delhi, applied for a visitor's visa and was turned down in no time flat. He was turned down and it was a great disappointment to the family. He went across the street or however far away the United States Embassy was and he got a visa in a very short order. He landed in New York.
The wedding was this past Sunday. To Mr. Gill and his family, I wish them congratulations and I hope the young couple has a very happily wedded life.
His brother who is now here would like to come from New York to Montreal to visit the rest of the family. Once again, the gentleman went with his brother, a Canadian citizen, to our office to explain his case. He was there as an interpreter. I would suggest that the immigration or the consulate office says that perhaps it spent 10 minutes with him, but according to my friend he felt that maybe it was five minutes. He said: "Really, it felt like one minute but maybe it was five to seven minutes. They did not even listen to me, Mrs. Finestone. They didn't listen when I said I had a letter from the bank attesting to the substance of my brother. I had a letter from the bank which is an affidavit as well to the land that this man owns. I had this letter describing the fact that he is a man who is married with a wife and two children". His daughter is presently in a masters program at the university in New Delhi and he has family and obligations. He is well-to-do and well established in his own country. He wants to come merely for a visit.
The assessment that was given to me was that this gentleman has no ties that would make him want to return to India. He has no ties to his home country, no stakes to go back to and therefore, he does not seem to be a good risk. Frankly, I find that to be a matter of personal judgment, number one; no criteria, number two; and quite inhuman in the course of the joys of those particular moments in life when one would like to have one's family present.
I certainly am very supportive of the amendments that are brought forward and I hope the government will be with respect to having within the bill certain criteria that will help the visa officers in very crowded offices overseas have guidelines. Then it will not be arbitrary. There will be guidelines. As a matter of right, certain decisions will be taken without using a discriminatory sense of what one thinks is a person's potential to evade the proper procedures of immigration to come here and perhaps claim refugee status, which was not the intent at all in the case I mentioned.
November 18, 1992

Government Orders
Therefore, the motion makes good sense. I hope the government will seriously consider "that a visa officer"-this is the amendment-"shall not refuse to issue a visitor's visa to a person who made an application pursuant to subsection (1) or any of the person's dependants where the person satisfies the visa officer that: (1) A person has a place of residence, immediate family and permanent employment in the person's country".
I heard my colleague from Vancouver describing just such cases which would have had no problems on landing had they had this mere, simple criteria. Second, "that the person and the person's dependants as the case may be have return tickets and intend to return to that country; or the person does not have a pending application for landing".
For the purposes of whatever paragraph 6 (b) is in this instance, "the fact that a person and the person's dependants will return to the person's country shall be presumed unless there is strong evidence to the contrary". I do not know why we have to presume everybody is filled with ill will and mauvaise entente, poor intentions. I think the world generally is a decent place and individuals on a one to one basis should be presumed to be innocent rather than be declared guilty before the fact.
That is the first of a series of amendments which I think are important. I hope that we will give serious support to a list of directions. I see the parliamentary secretary shaking her head no. That is not very helpful.

Besides which, she is not the minister of immigration, Madam Speaker, so I hope that the minister of immigration will be a little more open to this.
The second set of motions I would like to address has to do with the question of the resident requirements. Under resident requirements, a person is sent to live in a certain area. I am concerned about this being subject to a charter challenge and I would strongly represent the right of mobility rights for people who come to this country. Has the notwithstanding clause been put in here? If not, it is the only way this would stand a charter challenge, I believe.

Madam Speaker, I want to take this opportunity to speak to three of the amendments in the group, specifically Motions Nos. 3, 6 and 70, and I want to do so with some particularity.
Motion No. 3 deals with an applicant for an immigrant's visa. The section reads: "An application for an immigrant's visa shall". That is key because it is mandatory for the visa officer to consider the person making the application and every dependant of that person.
That is very important because the visa officer, therefore, must consider every dependant, whether or not that particular dependant is going to be accompanying the applicant to Canada. There have been many, many cases, and all of us in this House can cite them, where there has been unfairness because a person defined as a dependant under the immigration laws has prevented a family from coming to Canada even though that particular person who is defined as a dependant has no wish to come to Canada.
The intent, it seems to me, of Motion No. 3 is very clear, and that is to say all right, those who wish to come to Canada have to be considered, but those who are not accompanying the applicant should not affect the over-all application made by the applicant. That to me seems eminently reasonable. I stand to support it wholeheartedly. I am at a loss to understand what the department would find difficult about that. If there were some problem where later on somebody might make an application, one could always deal with that by way of regulation by saying that that particular dependant had to renounce or indicate that they would not use those who were allowed to come to Canada as a hook whereby they could come in.
There is a way of dealing with that without having to deny the entire application of the applicant and those dependants who would be accompanying the applicant, simply because another person defined as a dependant does not meet the criteria. I think Motion No. 3 is very, very reasonable and within the spirit of the Immigration Act and the proposed Bill C-86.
I would also like to speak in favour of Motion No. 6 put forward by my colleague, the hon. member for Scarborough-Rouge River. The House will remember that my colleague had a private member's bill which was, if not identical, very similar to this motion and which had an opportunity to be debated. I can tell you that from discussions with constituents of mine in the riding of

Scarborough West, this amendment is eminently reasonable in their view. It is very simple to explain.
Let us say someone wants their aunt to visit them. They say: "Listen, we realize that you are afraid that my aunt will not go back. What I will do is I will put up a guarantee in the form of a mortgage or a bond on my home. If this person that you allow in does not go back then I will forfeit that $25,000 or that $15,000, or $5,000 or whatever it may be". That is very, very reasonable. It shows the bona fides of the person who is making the application to have the visitor come in.
I am certain that if this amendment were allowed, if there was any abuse of the system once the Immigration department started cashing in on those performance bonds, in very short order the word would spread across Canada that the department means business. If there is a false application made the immigration department is going to call that performance bond. The point is that the fear of the immigration officer abroad that this particular visitor would not return would very quickly be dealt with.
Some might say that is unfair to those people who cannot put forward a bond. I say no because my hon. colleague has dealt with that in subsection 7 of his amendment which clearly says that the absence of any security described in subsection 6 shall not, -that is mandatory,- be taken into account in determining the question we have been talking about.
I think that in searching for a solution to a very difficult problem, my hon. friend has come up with a very reasonable proposal. It is not something that is new or unique, that has not been brought to the attention of the department. On the contrary, the department is perfectly aware of it. But for some reason, and I do not know quite what it is, it has failed to act on it.
Therefore I want to say unequivocally that I support this particular amendment and the idea behind it, which is clearly to permit people who are Canadian citizens or landed immigrants to have visits from their family and friends and to guarantee to the Government of Canada that those people are indeed visitors and not people who
are using visitor provisions to get here illegally. That is a reasonable proposal which helps, not hinders, the immigration system in this country and I hope that the government would consider it.
Finally, I would like to address Motion No. 70 which deals specifically with subsection 114(1) of the act. It talks about prescribing the classes of immigrants in respect of which landing shall be granted and then goes on to say that there can be terms and conditions imposed, including place of residence and occupation.
Some are worried about the charter implications. I would like to say I am one who is not concerned about the charter implications because the relevant section of the charter deals with citizens and landed immigrants or people with the status of landed immigrant.
Subsection (ii.2) of the proposed amendment clearly states that the department can prescribe classes of immigrants in respect of which landing shall be granted "subject to terms and conditions".
Of course one of those terms and conditions can be that you must live in a place for a certain period of time before we will grant you landed status. Therefore that person during that period of time is not landed and therefore is not within the definition provided in the Charter of Rights and Freedoms. To me these arguments about the Charter of Rights and Freedoms is a red herring.
Having said that, the amendment that we in this party have put forward provides a time limit. That time limit specifically states that where there is a condition concerning the place of residence and occupation, that time limit cannot be a period beyond two years.
That to me is a reasonable proposition. It accepts the principle that is in the section, which is the possible requirement concerning place of residence and occupation, and yet says you cannot abuse this. There will be a specific time limit that will be imposed, which will be a maximum of two years. It does not have to be two years. It can be less, but it certainly cannot be any more than that. That is fair. By that time the department should be able to determine whether or not the terms and condi-
November 18, 1992

tions have been met. If they have, landed status should be able to be granted.
These three amendments are perfectly reasonable. I find it unconscionable for no one in the government to be standing up and commenting on these amendments or indicating why they are wrong or why they are not going to be accepted or indeed if they are going to be accepted. If they are, why do we not just get on with it, approve these amendments by voice vote and go?
If we are going to have a bunch voting no, if we are going to have a recorded vote, if we are going to get up and vote against these amendments, surely someone over there should be telling us what is wrong with these proposed amendments. It is not as if we are changing the entire act. It is not as if we are changing even the intent of the act. We are accepting the principle for example in Motion No. 70, but we are asking that there be a reasonable time limit. Where are the people who are going to be speaking against these amendments and telling Canadians why these amendments are unacceptable? I cannot see why they are unacceptable. They seem perfectly reasonable. I know for a fact, from discussions across Canada and in my riding, that these kinds of amendments are acceptable to the people of Canada. They are acceptable to immigrant people who want people to visit them, who want their relatives and friends to be able to come here and who are now meeting a bureaucratic brick wall.
For example, Motion No. 6 comes up with a solution. It comes up with a ladder whereby these people can climb over that brick wall and bring their friends in. We hear nothing on the other side and yet there is also a protection to Canada from those who would abuse the system because the bond would be forfeited. We do not hear any reason why there is something wrong with putting a time limit on a term and condition to live in a particular place, but most Canadians would think that is a reasonable situation.
Where is the negative here? If there is no negative, why do we not pass these amendments?

Madam Speaker, I too would like to address a couple of the amendments set out in this grouping, perhaps starting with those dealing with visitor visas and the criteria being suggested to govern the granting of such visas.

However, I think that in considering Motion No. 74 we should have a thought as well for the general problem of retroactivity that afflicts this bill. There is major confusion at this point about which clauses in the new bill will be applied retroactively, and whether cases currently in the system will be continued or families made to reapply under the new regime established by this bill. The matter of visitor visa fees and immigrant fees are but one example.
