There are other examples. I would like to give a couple out of my case files in Edmonton. One involves a woman who has been trying to sponsor her parents and two siblings since July 1990. After two years, little had happened. It was only through the intervention of my office that the application had begun to be processed. In the meantime, the father has died and the family abroad are dependent on their family member in Canada for support. Under the new quota system that the bill provides, it would only be if the family were lucky enough to get into this year's allotment that their application would be processed, if retroactivity is applied.
There is a chap who applied to bring his wife and children from Vietnam in 1986. It took four years to process the case and then, due to a number of circumstances springing from that prolonged period, the case was delayed. For the last two years, the case has been tied up in workings between various embassies in southeast Asia. These delays have been largely the fault of our embassies and procedures. If the case is not processed before the bill comes into effect, again this family will have to compete for spaces if retroactivity is applied.
In fact, the active cases I have in my office right now number at least 50 that will be affected to some degree by the retroactivity provisions in this bill. Therefore, I heartily support Motion No. 74 and would ask again that the government at least make clear its intentions with regard to retroactivity in this bill, intentions which to this day remain murky.
Last, the matter of Motion No. 70 and precisely what the authorities may and may not do in directing where people live, how long they stay, what professions they seek, et cetera, I would just note that I have a constituent named Andrew. He came to Edmonton because of the large Polish community there, the community being his sponsor in Canada.
However, given the authority contemplated in the bill, had the government directed his settlement it might have sent him to the maritimes or to B.C. because he was a fisherman. Now of course, he would be an unemployed fisherman. He came to Edmonton, trained as a carpenter, and he has been able to work consistently at his new profession.
I am trying wherever possible to back up the argument on the motions with concrete examples from my own
experience of a constituency of average size, average population. This bill has serious flaws. They are flaws which at least are addressed and in part corrected by the motions we have before us in this grouping.
I now turn to the matter of visitors' visas and the utterly capricious way in which they are currently granted or withheld, the matter of the powers of the administration to direct people to do this. It has been correctly pointed out this will probably fall before a charter challenge. Also is the matter of retroactivity and what does or does not fall within retroactivity within the bill.
All of these things compel us to accept the amendments before us and I hope compel us, when we get the chance at third reading, to direct the government to go back and try again.

Mr. Speaker, in my riding of Ottawa Centre probably over 70 per cent of the work-load deals with both immigration and refugee cases. This is no different from any other urban riding anywhere in Canada.
Most of our colleagues in the House on a daily basis are faced with requests and questions from constituents, who are trying to bring in a family member as a visitor or as a landed immigrant or whether they have a friend who is a refugee claimant.
I want to say that our public servants have done an outstanding job in trying to keep up not only with the demands of the Canadian population, but also with the demands that members of Parliament and ministers are asking of them. Unfortunately throughout the past three years we have seen a tremendous increase in the work-load of our public servants, and we have seen a tremendous decrease in the numbers in the work force.
In other words, as we have more and more demands on the immigration offices and on embassies abroad, we have seen less and less manpower being allocated to those areas. We only have to look at some countries where there are waiting lists in excess of 5,000 applicants that are trying to get into the country. They have applied to come to Canada as landed immigrants and are waiting in desperate situations in some of those cases. Our public servants are doing their best to deal with it. Unfortunately with the present resources they cannot keep up with demands.
November 18, 1992

The same situation applies in the national capital region. In some cases applicants or constituents have to line up at the immigration offices an hour before the offices open so they have a chance to inquire about one case or another.
Rather than speak about the over-all bill I would like to focus on a couple of aspects. One aspect deals with work permits for refugees. Under the present law a work permit is issued to a refugee after he or she is recognized at the first stage, the credibility hearing. The present bill eliminates the first hearing and a refugee cannot obtain a work permit immediately. Therefore, a refugee claimant is forced to go on welfare and tremendous pressure is put on our social welfare system.
One of the motions that my colleagues have proposed would allow a refugee to obtain a work permit upon request, providing that a medical exam is passed. For the life of me I do not see why the government would not support a motion that would reduce the pressure on our social welfare system and would turn the refugee claimant who was waiting for his application to be processed into part of the work force. This is a very important motion and I hope the government will look at it with a positive eye.
Today I received a letter from Amnesty International which is extremely concerned about certain aspects of this bill and in particular about issues that deal with the refugee determination board.
Under the present bill, for a refugee to gain admission to Canada, his fate is decided by a senior immigration officer at the port of entry. At this stage a refugee claimant would have no right to a lawyer and would not automatically be given an oral hearing.
Amnesty International, through its communications and through its presentation to the committee, has requested that this be looked into and be addressed in a fair and reasonable way.
On another point, some claimants will only be accepted as refugees if there is a unanimous decision on the part of the board. I wonder what kind of a democracy we are living in that you would need a 100 per cent approval rate. It is known world-wide that in a democra-
Govemment Orders
cy, if 50 plus one have said yes, you proceed. This particular aspect of the bill will have to be addressed.
I must commend Amnesty International for its work on behalf of refugee claimants world-wide and I must also commend our public servants who have worked tirelessly trying to address some of the issues they are faced with.
We support certain parts of the bill that deal with those who try to abuse the refugee system. However, at the same time we have proposed a number of amendments that the government should look at with a compassionate eye.
If you ask me for my views on this whole aspect, amnesty should be granted to all the refugees coming from countries that have civil wars or other problems through some sort of an administrative system. In this way we could save millions of taxpayers' dollars rather than carrying on with a lengthy process that is not beneficial to anybody.
On a final note, the refugee processing system has cost the government in excess of $500 million so far. However, we do not yet have a grip on this situation. It is my hope that over the next few weeks the minister will look at this issue a little more closely and try to see whether he cannot grant amnesty to many of these people who come from war-tom countries. I think compassion is the key issue in helping to resolve their problems.
Again I reiterate the fact that many of the amendments are put before the government in good faith and it is my hope that it will address and deal with them in good faith too.

Mr. Speaker, I welcome this opportunity to join in the debate on Bill C-86.
The concerns of immigration policy are very much ones in which many members of this House share because of what happens back home in our constituencies. I know the member for Winnipeg North, who is participating in this debate, is also very concerned about the future of the Winnipeg immigration community because he and I share many of the same problems. He has done a great deal of work on behalf of constituents throughout Manitoba and across the country who have troubles dealing with the Immigration Act.

Government Orders
I would like to say at the outset that we should take a minute to thank the many public servants across the country and around the world who faithfully try to respond to our many requests for information and for clarification of the status of our constituents and who have to go through a great deal of paper work in order to make sure we have the best immigration policy in this country.
Whenever a request is made on behalf of constituents of Winnipeg North Centre the public servants are very generous with the time they spend on the cases and are very forthright in the way they try to deal with each individual case.
Immigration is an area which is of concern in Winnipeg North Centre because we have a large number of people who choose that part of Winnipeg as their first home in Canada. It is one of those areas in which, because of the inexpensive housing and the services available in the inner city, people choose to live to start out their lives. As they move up they move on to other cities or into the suburbs of Winnipeg. However, when they are first in Winnipeg they are very needy and we need to develop a system which is much more responsive to the problems facing new Canadians.
However, that is outside the content of Bill C-86 except for one important point. The spirit with which we deal with people from other countries as they arrive in Canada is one of the bench-marks we have used for our country as being a democratic and open society.
I have always been impressed by the way in which people, for example from Vietnam, the Indo-China Chinese community in Winnipeg, people from Hong Kong, mainland China, the Asian community itself has been brought to Winnipeg through refugee policies and settlement policies to seek out and make a living here. Then when they try to extend their roots by bringing other members of family, friends, or students within the extended family they find there are a number of barriers.
As we receive people from the rest of the world, we have to understand that it is in fact a changed process. We are not the society we were in 1900, not the society we were in 1950, and by the year 2000 we will be an entirely different society.
It is up to us in the House of Commons to make sure that we modernize laws so that they respond and respect
the people who are now to become part of our society. When it comes to issues of defining families and issues of trying to figure out which refugee is acceptable and which one is not, we have to remember we are not trying to make those definitions for the country that we were in the past but we are trying to make it for the country we are becoming and will become in the 21st century.
I say this because so many decisions do not come naturally and do not come easily. Let me put this case to you. In order to build up a family business, to make money in a strange society, people depend on family members whom they trust. It does not matter whether the person speaks the local language, the question is do they speak the language of the family. Can they be trusted with the cash? Do they know how to do a certain business like the lumber business? Have they been involved with it for generations?
When people start a small business in a strange society they want to work within the family until they are more confident of the culture, the business attitudes, and the ethics of a new society.
We are the host society to these businesses but we do not provide a generous environment. People say to their member of Parliament: "Sir, we want to bring in family members to help us with our business", which is a great idea, but when we face the regulatory process we find it almost impossible to assist them.
As we look at Bill C-86 we should be asking ourselves if we are modernizing the legislation in such a way as to help those who are coming to Canada become more deeply rooted and more successful financially, so that when we look ahead we have the people who form the core of our new business and professional classes and who will become our teachers, our business people and the owners of large businesses.
We must deal with the macro-economic question, which people do not usually associate with the immigration issue. The major problem that faces the Canadian economy has been the total collapse of many of the traditional sectors that we have depended upon, and manufacturing has been mentioned several times in this House of Commons. However, to move beyond that, the problem is a depletion of capital.
November 18, 1992

As we have experienced the Americanization and globalization of the economy the ability of Canadians to compete has been severely limited. We have talked about this on many different occasions. However, if we are going to be practical and if we are looking at ways to rebuild the economy, who are going to best be able to adjust to the new markets in Asia? Who are going to best be able to adjust to the markets in the Philippines? Who are going to best be able to understand what is happening in eastern Europe? Who are going to best be able to set up small firms in this country and take the inter-generational approach to building up capital and reaching out to these markets?
They are not the companies that are closing down factories. They are not the companies that are pulling out of Ontario and the maritimes and have pulled out of Manitoba. They will be new companies that we cannot even imagine as we stand in the House and talk about this issue.
The cornerstone to the economic revival of this country will be a revised and modernized Immigration Act.
We, on this side, were very disappointed to hear today that the government was using time allocation to speed the debate up and push this piece of legislation through. The bill is extremely long and complex, with 128 sections and 113 pages. It is the most extensive revision to the Immigration Act since 1978, and it deserves careful consideration.
The committee met all summer and heard from dozens of groups across the country. These groups were well organized and spoke against what the government was trying to do. Even in this context the changes have been done quickly and are not fully understood at this time.
In these circumstances the government's original handling of the bill was deplorable. The bill was tabled for a first reading on June 16, 1992 and called for a second reading debate on June 19. The vote on second reading was forced under a closure order on June 22 with only one and a half days of debate. Consequently, there was not enough time to examine the bill in detail or to discuss it with immigration experts and NGOs.
Government Orders
I raise this issue because in the debate that I have had in this House about the child benefits package I have found that there was the same rush, the same inability to discuss things intelligently and the same inability to bring in good witnesses. In fact, when good witnesses did appear in the middle of the summer, which was the only time the government had to meet with them, every one of these witnesses said that this was a bad piece of legislation. However, the government continued.
I hope and I trust, in the spirit of goodwill which prevails from time to time in this House, that the minister will listen to the opposition's point that it is not necessary to push, push, push and change some of the fundamentals of our immigration law without considering the implications.
Under severe criticism from all parts of the country the government finally became more flexible and committee hearings took place during the summer. The clause-by-clause examination of the bill was completed in committee on November 5, 1992, and during the clause-by-clause process the government agreed to 65 amendments. Some of these were technical but others were substantial and have led to a certain improvement in the bill. To that extent, we congratulate the government on being flexible in receiving these changes.
Nevertheless, many key offensive sections were not amended and the bill as a whole is still unacceptable to us.
There are four major points we would like to make on the consideration and which our critics, the members from Notre-Dame-de-Grace and Thunder Bay who have done a tremendous job in responding to this piece of legislation, would like Canadians to be aware of.
First, it would make it more difficult for law-abiding, hard-working immigrants to enter Canada, which is exactly what we do not want. Second, it puts barriers in the way of legitimate refugees. Third, it opens the door to inequity and capriciousness in the selection of immigrants. Fourth, it suspends traditional legal safeguards, especially in the areas of deportation without hearings, suspension of rights through retroactive provisions and so forth.

Government Orders
We also oppose the bill for two other reasons. One, there is an emphasis on enforcement as opposed to fairness and humanitarian values. Two, too much power has been transferred from the law and the House of Commons to the authority of the minister, which leaves the whole process open to abuse.
The Liberal caucus is providing a number of amendments that I would like the House to consider. We have provided amendments with regard to the provisions of how the assessment takes place with family members, with visitors' visas. It is unbelievable how difficult it is for people from many countries to come and visit family. We can almost say that the process is so biased against people from these countries that it borders on being an embarrassment to all Canadians. We have provided amendments dealing with work permits and many other areas.
Time is limited in a debate like this. However, although an overhaul of this legislation is badly needed I would like to say that this bill is a bad bill. We wish the government would withdraw it.

Mr. Speaker, I appreciate the opportunity to speak on Bill C-86. These are the first amendments of any extent that have been made since 1978. There are many, many good things in this bill. What we are trying to do as a party is make the bill even better.
The proposed improvements to the bill have been a long time coming, but there are still some parts of the bill that are unacceptable.
Speak your mind.

The member from the other side is giving us encouragement to speak our minds and that is precisely what we intend to do.
In my view, one thing about this bill that should be noted is that it will make it more difficult for law-abiding, hard-working immigrants to enter Canada and will put barriers in the way of legitimate refugees.
I refer to the section on family members. The bill provides that the government can assess all members of a family when they are deciding on the immigration application of one member of that family. We are opposed to that provision. Through this amendment we
propose that an individual should only be assessed with respect to those members of his or her family who accompany him or her to Canada under the application.
It begs the question as to how we can accept the fact that "the sins of the father are visited upon the sons" or vice versa. It seems to me that many people might be kept out because of some failure of another member of the family who at that point is not even applying to come into the country.
It is unfair to keep out an entire family because one brother or sister may have legal difficulties in his or her own country or might be a political activist who does not wish to come to Canada with the rest of the family, although I cannot for the life of me understand why anyone would not want to come to Canada. There are millions of people who are trying to get into this country.
In my view, this is the method by which the government hopes to keep out large families. Large families are a fact of life in most parts of this planet. I do not think that it is right that one person in a family, who may or may not be trying to come into this country, can keep the others from getting in because of some indiscretion or even misdemeanour.
My second point concerns visitors' visas. The bill does very little to improve the law or administration with respect to the granting of visitors' visas.
At the present time there are many incidents in which Canadians wish to bring members of their family to this country as visitors but are turned down. This happens consistently. The reason they are being turned down is because of situations in which immigration officers believe, rightly or wrongly, that they want to come in on a visitor's visa but they ultimately want to stay in the country.
We are prejudging them, we are giving to them motives which they may or may not have. I believe that we should at least take them at face value. If we find that they are coming into the country and abusing the system then they can be deported. My understanding of deportation is that when they are deported they should not be allowed to enter the country at a later time. That should be one of the items of basic fairness that we must examine and should have to live with.
November 18, 1992

I would like to address two other small areas and then expand from there.
The first is the residence requirement. The bill provides that conditions can be placed on an immigration visa obliging a person to live and work in a certain community. While the government agreed to amendments in committee which would moderate this situation it is still not acceptable.
Here I am of two minds. On the one hand, I believe that people coming in to Canada should accept, for a short time perhaps, working in certain areas in the country or landing in certain areas of the country. On the other hand, I am a little bit distressed. If we can do that to immigrants coming in then I wonder if we can at some later time also hope to do the same thing to other Canadian citizens.
Personally, I am a little bit reluctant to agree to the residence requirement although I can see that, at least initially, when a person enters the country it should be one thing we at least should consider.
I note here also that the Senate committee proposed a similar amendment. Perhaps more work could be done in that particular area.
In years gone by, with regard to immigration, people who came in from another country would-I do not know if I would use the word indentured, but it would be close to it-be given jobs working on certain farms, for example in the west or the north, or to put it another way in our under-populated areas. While this might seem to be a solution to some of our current problems it could have long-term ramifications for all Canadians. It is for this reason that I am reluctant to whole-heartedly back this particular amendment.
Another area is the refund of immigration fees. Bill C-86 proposes retroactive changes to the processing of immigration applications, including the suspension and cancellation of applications even after they have been moved considerably along the approval process.
In this amendment we say that if an application is cancelled after it had originally been accepted for processing then the fees for application should be refunded to the applicant. That seems fair to me. At the present time there is a fee of $350 for each immigrant application, and that represents a lot of money for people in Third World countries.
Government Orders
I do not denounce this bill completely. There are some things that are still not acceptable. However, with these few added amendments that we made in addition to the ones that have already been accepted-and we put in 65 amendments from this side of the floor-it would perhaps be worthy of our consideration.
A few other reasons that this bill is not acceptable in its present form is that it opens the door to inequity and capriciousness in the selection of immigrants. It suspends traditional legal safeguards, that is to say deportations without hearings and suspension of rights through retroactive provisions. I just do not like that. There is an emphasis on enforcement as opposed to fairness and humanitarian values. It must be noted that over the years we have been known as a very humane society. We have opened our doors and our hearts to immigrants from all lands. That is why Canadians are able to proceed, I hope harmoniously, for the duration of history. Over the years we have not had the racial unrest that has typified many of the other countries of the world. Witness Germany where there is this backlash of, we are told, right-wing neo-Nazis who want to close their doors to the opportunity for people coming in from the Third World.
We do not want that here and I am sure we are able to absorb not only the immigrants who have been coming in, but who will be coming in in the years ahead and we should be able to accept them with open arms.
I have found in my experience that most of these men and women want to come to this country to start a new and better life for themselves and for their children. It is very important for them to at least have their chance.
I do not say we should allow just anyone to come into the country. Yes, there must be criteria. There must be standards, but I think Canadians can learn to live with these standards. Even more than that, we must open up our boundaries to men and women who want to help us build a stronger and better country.
Finally, I feel that too much has been transferred from the law and the House of Commons to the authority of the minister. That leaves the whole process open to abuse. I do not in any way criticize the minister as being dishonest or anything like that. It is just that ministers, like all human beings, are fallible. In their fallibility they are prone many times to overlook other circumstances or people which in some way would reflect on the over-all aspect of Canada which we want seen in the world.

Government Orders
Immigrants have been and continue to be in many ways the backbone of our growth. We need new people to help us as a nation. Our nation over the years has grown because of new ideas which have been brought in. It ill behoves us to make conditions so difficult for immigrants coming in that they would not want to come to our shores, to our cities and to our homes and build a better country.
We are, after all, as has been said many times by my colleagues in this House, a nation of immigrants. We are a large nation geographically with a small population. We are told we can easily accommodate as many as 50 million to 60 million people on the land area that we have.
I think we should be looking in the years ahead to expand our population because quite frankly the world needs us as a representative of what the world could be. This is a nation where people can get along with one another and a nation where people can grow. This is precisely what we have in Canada and what we are offering to all citizens who want to come to our shores.

Mr. Speaker, I welcome the opportunity to say a few words on an issue that is very close to my heart. Bill C-86 concerns amendments to the Immigration Act.
I stand as a former immigrant to Canada. I must say that when I immigrated in 1956 I was-and I still am- indeed very grateful to Canada for having accepted me as an immigrant. I think this spirit which I try to exemplify in terms of contributing to Canadian life is one that is exhibited by 99.99 per cent of the people who chose Canada and who were accepted by Canada as immigrants.
In fact, immigrants have contributed much to the development of Canada. There is not a sphere of life in Canada that has not been touched by the contributions of immigrants from all comers of the world. I wonder why, in its attempt to amend the Immigration Act, this government seems to have pandered to particularly the Reform Party ideology and philosophy of trying to close the door or make it more difficult for immigrants to come to Canada.
Immigrants have created employment in Canada. They do not take employment away from Canadians. They are vital to the professional life of Canada, to the economic
life of Canada and to the cultural life of Canada. This is one of the few countries that in fact has multicultural laws that reflect and stress the importance of immigrants to Canada.
I find it very strange and very difficult to understand why a government would do some of the cruel things it is proposing in the legislation. An example is saying that you can send someone who comes as an immigrant to a part of the country without any kind of time limits and keep them there. In fact, an immigrant can come to Canada and he can bring with him all his dependants, but if there is one dependant left back in the other country, then that particular dependant would have to go through the whole rigmarole of applying, being sponsored or whatever else. We all know from experience in our riding offices the red tape and the rigmarole. As time goes on they could turn 19 and then they would have to re-apply as an independent.
There is the cruelty of refusing a refund to someone who has applied to become an immigrant to Canada after they pay the fee and decide not to go through with it or for some reason they are not passed. They cannot get their $300 or $350 back.
Maybe to the government members $350 is not a lot of money, but from where I come $350 represents a huge amount of money. Where I come from there is an exchange rate where $10 Canadian equals $100 Guyanese. That is $3,500. It is a humungous amount of money. And yet this government is proposing this particular change to the Immigration Act.
Along with my colleagues who served on the committee, we found there was not one group that supported these changes. Look at what happened. The government brought to the committee 70 amendments to a bill that has 100 pages. The government brought 70 changes and then another 11.
Not one group came before the committee. Ask my colleagues who sat on that committee. Not one group gave their okay to these changes. They all made these arguments much more eloquently than I can make them. Yet, this government using polls and tapping in to the xenophobia which we all know exists in the Canadian population, pandering to it and maybe trying to vault itself in the polls in terms of its popularity on the backs of immigrants is totally, totally unacceptable. It is absolutely shameful. It is not in the finest traditions of Canada.
November 18, 1992

My colleague from Spadina and my colleague for Thunder Bay-Nipigon have made some very thoughtful and fair amendments to try and make the bill more humane. To put a time limit of two years on where a person can be designated on their arrival is very wise. It seems to me that the government should accept that. What is wrong with accepting that? Is there a good reason. I hope the government spokesperson who will respond can give us a good reason and I do not want fluff. I do not want flim-flam and I do not want him to try any jiggery-pokery in this House.
I want to hear specific concrete reasons. I want the government spokesman to respond specifically to the other amendment of my colleague for Thunder Bay- Nipigon, the question of refunding people their money where an application is withdrawn and disallowed. I want to hear why you cannot do that. I want to hear from the minister's representative specific reasons why that amendment cannot be allowed.
I want to hear why the amendment of my colleague from Spadina cannot be allowed, the one where the family comes and brings the dependants but there are one or two dependants left in the other place. Why can they not do the paperwork to bring them at a later date. It could very well be that the dependant may be in school. He has to complete his school year.
Do not put your hands up in a pleading way. I want to hear why that cannot be processed at the same time and not have that dependant at a later date go through the rigmarole and the red tape that we all have to deal with in our riding offices.
Last, I have known through my office the power that is placed in the hands of the immigration officer in the other country where a person applies for a visitor's visa. A family member has died in Canada. It could be a father, a brother, a sister or a mother. What they put that person through. Often times they are denied the visitor's visa. By the time they get to the MP for us to go through the bureaucracy in Ottawa or even to the minister, the person has been buried. In some cases, the
Government Orders
culture does not allow the person to be buried until that close relative is there.
Does the government not understand the sensitivity of that? Does this government not understand that? Yet, that immigration officer can simply say: "Well, I have detected in the demeanour when I interviewed the person in the New Delhi office that they do not want to come as a visitor and they might try to stay. They are not a bona fide visitor".
That is an awful lot of power. I think we ought to turn the tables around so that the person applying for the visitor's visa should have the onus placed on the immigration officer to prove. He does not have to prove anything. It leaves open whether it is a bias or prejudice. I do not think that is fair. We need to reverse the onus.

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I am quite happy to stand and speak in favour of these amendments to Bill C-86 which makes changes to the Immigration Act.
I am also pleased to be following my colleague from Nickel Belt. I must say that while many times I do not agree with his politics, I do feel that the member for Nickel Belt has added greatly to the culture in our country and to the culture in my riding with his colourful attitude and his very worth-while thoughts from time to time.
I still have a lot of work to do to get him convinced of some of my ways, but I will keep working on that. As you know, my colleague from Nickel Belt did immigrate at some point 20 or 30 years ago. I hate to tell you how old he is, but he is older than I am and that makes it better.
At any rate, I have to say that immigration is, of course, the backbone of our country. While many of us may have forgotten, most of us here if we go back far enough, are descendants of immigrants of one sort or another.
I think it is absolutely essential that we continue the tradition of Canadian immigration, that is, we welcome people from all over the world to come and share this land that we have, to help us build it and to become truly great Canadians as many, many immigrants have become.
I was bom in the town of Kirkland Lake. Whether you are aware of it or not, after the Second World War Kirkland Lake, being a mining town, had many jobs at that time and many immigrants came and settled there. We learned many things. We learned hard work. We learned that they valued family greatly, and they certainly appreciated becoming Canadians. It was truly a momentous occasion for them who had had such great trials and tribulations during the war. They contributed to Canada and they have made it a different and I believe much better place.
When I became an adult I moved to Sudbury, another area where very much immigration has taken place over many years. There again you can see a model of what it is like where everyone lives together, works together and builds together, which we have done. There are people from every comer of the earth there. It is a wonderful community to use as an example for others who may not understand the value of immigration and how well it can function.
I look at some of these changes that are being proposed. I want to tell the people of this government about what happens when one of these immigrants who are now Canadians invites a member of his or her family, say from Poland, to come and visit. As you know, for very many years these people have not been able to travel freely and come to Canada. It is only in the last few years that they have had an opportunity to do so and to leave their country.
Many times they go to the Canadian consulate and they are denied a visitor's visa. Often it is because the person who is coming does not really understand the questions that are being asked. They are refused. The families are heart-broken because they would really like to have the opportunity to show the family that was left behind, say in Poland or in one of the eastern bloc countries, what their life has become, and to share with them a little bit over a few weeks some of the bounty that they have.
Many times I have had families from my riding come to see me to see if we can help. I must always explain that one way of getting this visitor's visa is to show that you own your home, that you have a job and a life in your country, and that there is no reason why you would want to stay in Canada, that you really only want to come for a visit.
November 18, 1992

I think it is especially important nowadays that we become more flexible, not less flexible, when it comes to issuing visitors' visas.
One of the other amendments here would provide that they not assess the whole family based on whether one brother is perhaps not what he should be. In most families there is a black sheep. You do not control everything your brothers and sisters do. A family may be denied the right to come to Canada because that family may have one brother or sister who is not doing things the way they would do them. Why would we judge the whole family by the actions of one? That is very, very serious. I would hope that we are more humane than that. It is very important that we treat people with respect. In that way we will be treated with respect.
One of the other problems with immigration is that often people pay to apply, and for some reason or another the application which was originally accepted is rejected. We have talked about how $350 does not seem like a large amount of money to us, although it is for many Canadians. It is something many people do not have quite at their fingertips. For some of these people it may even represent almost a year's worth, or two or three year's worth of savings.
That application money should be refunded. I think it is only fair that we treat people with some kind of respect. Often the application has been paid for perhaps by a Canadian family wishing to sponsor a relative. They may try again and again to sponsor this relative. To have them spend $350 every time gets to be a little bit expensive, especially if the application is first accepted and then rejected. I would like to see that kind of humanness put into the system.
The other thing is the residence requirement. I am all for encouraging immigrants to spend a certain amount of time in a certain area. I believe that there are times when we would want more people to come and settle in certain areas where there is a high demand for employment and perhaps it is difficult to get people to live there, but not for an extended period of time. It should be no more than two years. Often after two years they will be able to move on.
I am being told that my time is up. I want to say though that I would hope that the members of the government would show some humanness, some kindness and remember that somewhere along the way Canada wel-
Govemment Orders
corned us, or welcomed our fathers or our great-great-grandfathers. Basically most of us are immigrants. Let us make sure that we keep on being as humane and compassionate as people were then.

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I appreciate the opportunity to speak in this debate. I appreciate the opportunity to respond on behalf of the government. First and foremost, it is essential to say that this legislation ensures that the system we have in place will enable us in the future to bring people into this country who choose to become Canadians and my personal view and my personal hope is that it is in ever increasing numbers.
The second thing is that the system must ensure that those who need our protection from persecution around the world, who have not found refuge elsewhere can find refuge and protection in this country and that our tradition of leading the world in this area will be maintained and continued. It is essential that we have a system which is visible and a system which Canadians have confidence in. I fear that if we lose confidence in this system, Canadians will not tolerate the high numbers of immigrants we have seen in the past seven or eight years and will not tolerate increases in numbers of immigrants in the future.
I would like to comment very briefly on the six or seven points raised in this group of amendments. The first refers to Motion No. 3 which involves the question of accompanying dependants. I think it should be recognized first of all that the premise of the 1976 legislation was that all dependants or all applications for immigrant status were to be handled outside of the country.
The provision here is in fact a large step forward. What we have also done is ensure that visitors, when applying to come to Canada, only get assessed on the people who are coming with them and that refugees get a special consideration as they are considered as family units.

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I refer to clause 5, which refers to the question of criteria against which visitors' visas may be measured, and at the same time to Motion No. 7 from my friend for Scarborough-Rouge River. There is no question that we have all experienced a great deal of difficulty in dealing with visitors and visitors' visas. I will tell you and it is no surprise to this House that this is a tremendous problem for those held responsible for administering the immigration system and the people who are in the field representing Canada abroad.
I may say that the proposal of the hon. member for Scarborough-Rouge River as an idea and as a policy holds some merit. There are some fundamental flaws in the system, however, which need to be looked at. One of the big difficulties we have is in prescribing criteria like this in a piece of legislation. Courts use that legislation as a strong measurement. If those are prescribed in the act and there is a problem in that the courts are interpreting them either much more strictly than they were intended or too leniently, we run into a problem in terms of fixing them. In fact, perhaps the best place to accomplish this would be in the regulations. As others have done, I caution against the fear that it becomes a capacity-to-pay privilege rather than a protection that is guaranteed by Canadians and those in this country who are prepared to put their resources behind their commitment.
I would like to refer to the question of mobility, Motion No. 70. On the question of the charter applying, first of all it should be recognized that the charter applies to the government, not to the people to whom the government applies the charter. That is more accurate than as has, perhaps, been said before. It may come under charter challenge but I think it is important to recognize exactly what the mobility provisions provide. For those people who might not normally have the
opportunity to come to Canada because they would want to come to Montreal, Toronto or Vancouver, if there is employment in place and if there are support mechanisms in place, those people can come and live in the more remote parts of the country.
There were some real concerns raised in the hearings and we have addressed those, particularly as they involve the variance of conditions. We have provided in section 15 not only for the variance of conditions but also that the visa or immigration officer must vary those conditions. I think that is important and it is an important change.
In terms of the time frame, why should we limit it to two years? On the top end citizenship comes in three years. They would disappear. There may be circumstances where we would only want to put the conditions in place for one year. I would argue that two years is far too restrictive.
Very quickly, on the question of a fee, it is not an admission fee to Canada. The fee is a processing fee for the application and it should be recognized that the minister has made it clear and the evidence in the hearings has made it clear that the processing fee for those who have applied and have had their applications denied without any process or because of retroactivity or changes in policy will, in fact, have that fee refunded. There are opportunities in the regulations that would provide to have fees changed or taken into account if necessary.
One minute to conclude, Mr. Speaker, because I know you would like to have the opportunity to put this forward.
I think it is important to recognize that a number of people came before the committee on this legislation with a variety of views, a great deal of them very valid. The government responded as well to the opposition to say that this legislation is cruel and ridiculous. To say that nobody came forward in support of it is inaccurate and unfair. If one looks at the evidence, the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, the IRB and the Senate report, the government has addressed a number of those considerations. I would remind my friend opposite that in fact one of the groups that came forward, in fact one of the least fettered sources of support, was the union that represents the workers of Employment and Immigration Canada.

speakeroldname: Mr. Benno Friesen (Parliamentary Secretary to Secretary of State for External Affairs):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Secretary of State for External Affairs
subtopic: CROSS-BORDER SHOPPING EXPORT AND IMPORT PERMITS
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, my constituency deserves more respect than that, sir.
I take pleasure in rising to speak on this motion introduced by my colleague and friend, the member for Perth-Wellington-Waterloo. The subject is really about cross-border shopping and the impact that has had particularly on the food-producing community and especially the farm and poultry community in Canada.
I have learned through the years that whenever one introduces an issue like this, there is an equal and opposite reaction to that motion somewhere else. There is not a thing we do in this House that does not affect another part of the community. In this case we are talking about the food producers of our land and they are, I guess, pitted so often against the consumer. It is unwitting and certainly not because producers want it that way. The consumer, however, wants low food prices and the producer wants to have cost recovery and some profit. This is understandable.
It has always been a mystery to me that those of us who are consumers feel free to organize in labour or trade unions. We feel that the employer is entitled to organize into employer groups and protect the business. The unions protect the interests of the workers so that they can have higher wages and better working conditions and the employer wants to protect his business so he can ensure his profits.
However, the consumer groups, when they band together, complain about marketing boards or supply management. I have never been able to understand why it was okay for the consumer groups to organize to protect themselves and protect their livelihood and act as though that does not increase the cost for the other people. That is, if the auto workers get a better wage it does not increase the price of cars, does it? They feel that they are entitled to that, but when farmers band together and form supply management systems and regimes to make sure that they get a return on their investment and maybe some profit, that somehow is scandalized by the consumer community. They think that is unfair.
I do not think it is unfair. I am not saying that I always agree with everything that the supply management system does, but I think that they are entitled to organize just as much as any other group is entitled to organize.
As I said, we are pitting the producer against the consumer in this issue unfortunately. It shows itself most vividly in cross-border shopping because everybody is looking for cheaper prices. They will willingly go into the United States where dairy products are subsidized many times up to the tune of 50 per cent and where the

American taxpayer is helping to subsidize those farm products. We do not mind that, but we are saying that it is okay to go there and buy those products and ding the Canadian farmer out of his business.
I can tell you that in the Fraser Valley of British Columbia the estimate is $50 million to $60 million lost by the farmers of British Columbia every year from milk being brought in in the trunks of cars across the border. I understand why the consumer, with the squeeze on the cost of food nowadays, wants those cheaper prices, but how many dairy farmers have been driven out of business because of milk, eggs or chickens being brought across the border in the trunks of cars?
On the one hand we want to protect the Canadian farms because if we blacktop all of them, the prices will surely go up in the United States and they will have us entrapped.
The government on the other hand is trying to make it easy for the consumer by making transit across the border easy. This is something which every consumer should be able to enjoy. I agree with that. My own riding has the busiest border-crossing point west of Windsor and we have done a lot. The Minister of National Revenue has done a lot. He has opened special lanes for tourists. There is a pace lane at Douglas. He has increased the resources and the staff, introduced new technology, streamlined the enforcement procedures and instituted automatic cash machines providing gains of 70 per cent. The list goes on and on. Incidentally, he also improved the plants and the offices so that the mayor of Abbotsford, George Ferguson, has said that upgrading that border crossing at Sumas is encouraging Americans to come through at California, Oregon and Washington. On the one hand we want those people coming and spending their dollars. On the other hand, at the same time, we are saying we want ease for Canadians to go shopping in the United States.
They should also be aware of what that does to the Canadian producer. My colleague has introduced a motion which has called for a 48-hour delay in poultry and dairy products being brought into Canada. If Canadian consumers go down into the United States and buy dairy products there would be a 48-hour delay in bringing them into Canada by changing the permit system for importing them.
Private Members' Business
That complicates it even more for the government I hasten to say because if you have a 48-hour delay, the consumer cannot stay there and wait for the 48 hours. That means storage facilities. It becomes a terribly complex problem. Incidentally, I have not even mentioned the impact this has on the merchants in Canada for those who are at the border who experience a loss of business because of the cross-border shopping.
We want, on the one hand, to protect the rights of Canadians for free and easy access across the border. That ought to be. We believe in free trade. We want them to be able to move across the border at ease. We should also be aware of the impact that has on the commercial side, the merchants in Canada, and certainly on the food producer side.
My colleague has introduced this motion in representing a farming community. He is trying to do his part to make sure that the interests of the farming groups are protected by the system, but at the same time he recognizes that it is much more complex than that.
There have been discussions regarding the means to implement this procedure and it is not a simple yes or no vote in the House that will solve the problem because it means incredibly costly expenditures to bring about the procedures at the border that would allow us to implement this particular motion if we were going to do it. At the same time we want to do something tangible that will protect the farmers.
What are we going to do? As I said at the outset of my remarks, we want to protect the farmers, we want to protect the consumers, we want to protect the merchants and we are caught in that squeeze. Four hours of debate does not really elevate the intricacies of the issue to the degree that we need.
We have agreed that there should be a much more intense study of the problem and that we should be able to bring people into a discussion on this so we can hear from experts in the farming and commercial communities, from Revenue Canada officials and be able to define even more accurately what the issues are and how we can solve them.

My colleague has written a statement I would like to read and put on the record. The member for Perth- Wellington-Waterloo has said: "Therefore I am pleased that the government has assured me that the subject matter of this motion will become a topic of a special committee study regardless of the outcome of the vote. I have also been assured that such a committee could continue through any prorogation if a House order is obtained".
I believe we have now concluded three hours of debate. Obviously there is much more that could be said about this subject. The farming community must be protected. The customs system must be able to operate at the border. We have to reduce the cost of enforcement at the border as we have been trying to do. We have to make it as efficient as possible at the border.
We have agreed that regardless of the vote tonight, there will be a special committee established, which has been lobbied for by the member from Perth, to make certain that all of the relevant issues are brought to the surface so we can come to a thorough understanding conclusion of this matter and we can do something tangible for the farmers of our country.

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, it is a pleasure to support my colleague from Perth-Wellington-Waterloo who moved this motion. As the previous speaker started his speech, I too support marketing boards and the organized marketing procedures we use in Canada, which work well. Our party supports marketing boards.
I think this private member's motion supports, perhaps in an indirect fashion, marketing boards. I will just speak about dairy in this case, although his motion goes a little further than that, it goes into poultry too.
Marketing boards are responsible for giving us a superior product in the dairy industry. It is always in good supply, the highest quality at a fair price. Even if we take inflated dollars into account, the price of food in this country is still a fair price compared to other countries. In some instances, compared over the last few years, there may be even a decline in the price of food, which
tells me something is working and there is some stability where marketing boards are involved.
I get a little nervous sometimes when we are told that once again GATT is down to the final hours. Those are the big players. There are 108 countries involved. Canada is not a big player in that GATT deal, but we certainly could be affected by it.
Our party has been consistent. We will protect marketing boards. The domestic market in this country is not up for grabs. That has been established. No Canadian wants Canada to become the dumping ground of the world for cheap dairy and poultry products. That is what marketing boards are endeavouring to protect. I do not think any Canadian would want to see a change from what it is right now where we have the best product that can be produced at a fair price.
I live in a border community. I know the consequences to to my part of the country of cross-border shopping. This item my colleague has brought forward in his private member's motion is one of the main culprits. Cross-border shopping has had a devastating effect on some small border communities. We put out some ideas periodically in the House as to what we think would correct this problem, but nothing has been done of any substantive nature.
The most recent article I have read is in one of Toronto's papers yesterday. It stated: "Same-day trips to the U.S. are on the rise". Anyone who thought that we had snuffed out cross-border shopping had better look at the facts.
The difficulty with the importing of dairy and poultry products under this general import permit is that people can bring in $20 worth of product as often as they like. They could conceivably go back and forth across the bridge several times a day, each time bringing back $20 worth of product. If a person is accompanied by his neighbour, he is entitled to bring $20 worth too. That would be $40 worth of milk for example. Forty dollars worth of milk is a lot of milk. He is supposed to be bringing it over for his own personal use. Sometimes I wonder.
The fact is he would pay duty on that, I suppose, if he wanted to go strictly by the law, but 10 per cent duty on dairy products would amount to about $2. It is customary at customs to waive anything in the neighbourhood of $2 or a little less or a little more. There is no incentive not to keep bringing the product across as many times as you
November 18, 1992

like. This is having a very serious impact on the dairy and poultry industries in this country. Higher amounts occasionally are waived. Sometimes they do not stick to just $2. If they happen to be busy in customs, you can imagine what happens, they wave you on and you can have much more than $20 worth.
There is nothing to prevent an importer, somebody who is bringing it across, from going back and forth as many times as he likes. There is nothing wrong with that except it has a bad effect on the controlled marketing system that we have in this country. We think this marketing system is one of the best, and we think it should be protected.
Statistics will show, and they are there for the reading, that this has caused serious problems with the producers, the processors and the retailers. We are not talking about a few thousand dollars. We are talking about several million dollars annually being lost because people can run back and forth bringing back $20 worth each time.
This proposal that my colleague is presenting has the support and indeed, I think it originated with the dairy farmers of Canada who have made a study of this problem. They would like to see the general import permit changed in about three or four areas. The dairy industry happens to be permit number one, and it would like to have it changed, as my colleague has mentioned, so that a person would have to stay in the United States for a period of 48 hours, after which time he would be entitled to bring across $20 worth. That would not correct it totally. We would have some problems with it still, but it would make a great start. We want to cause a slowdown in this flood of milk that is coming across the border and turn it into a trickle. That is all my colleague across the way is trying to do, he is trying to institute an amendment that could be put in place.
Apparently this matter has been studied and Canada has the authority. There is nothing wrong with putting this amendment in place. It would conform with any rules that we have regarding free trade or any rules that we have regarding GAIT. Therefore, I think it deserves support. I would like to see us support it. Our party will support it.
The dairy farmers of Canada need our support right now. We are supporting their marketing system. We would like to see it enhanced, of course, and we would
Private Members' Business
like to see some clarification at GATT of article XI but those things will happen. It would be a good start if we could get this much done.
This could be done without causing great hardship. It is not intended to cause great hardship to anybody. If the rules were applied fairly, I suppose most people would bring $20 worth of product across once in a while and use it. That was the intention, but that was before there was a lot of running back and forth cross-border shopping. When this measure was put in place, perhaps there was not any particular advantage to going across and bringing back dairy or poultry products. That is not the case today.
My colleague is just trying to bring the rules up to date a bit. Circumstances are different out there today and I think that is what his amendment would do, change the rules in three or four areas. He speaks of poultry and dairy products and they are under four categories as far as the rules go.
I am pleased on behalf of our party-there may be other speakers too-to support his endeavours. I hope that something will be done. As I say, it would not be a great hardship to anybody. It is not as if it is very severe. We are just proposing that a stay in the States be for 48 hours before bringing across some dairy and poultry products. There would be no harm done. It would help stem the flow which dairy farmers tell us is having a severe impact on their industry.
It is a pleasure for me, personally, to support my colleague's private member's motion and I know I speak on behalf of my party.

Mr. Speaker, I would like to add my comments on this motion and emphasize that we in the Bloc Quebecois thoroughly agree with what it proposes to do. The mover of the motion deserves our congratulations. It is like a breath of fresh air to see a Tory member mindful of the concerns of his constituents and those of Quebecers and Canadians in general.
The mandatory 48-hour stay will definitely help small producers who are often located along the border and even those who are further away, now that changing consumer habits are becoming a threat, both in Canada and Quebec. The mandatory 48-hour stay will certainly help our farmers who, as you know, live with a lot of uncertainty and are often very worried about the outcome of the GATT talks.

Private Members' Business
As my learned colleague said before, there is a direct connection with our marketing board system. Our new marketing boards have been instrumental in maintaining prices and ensuring security of supply. As far as quality is concerned, if we compare what is produced in this country, in Quebec or the rest of Canada, product quality is quite superior, when we look at what is on supermarket shelves, because of better quality control. And since we use our marketing boards to regulate Canadian or Quebec consumption, we have a duty to protect those marketing boards, as the hon. member said. This motion reflects the need to listen to what our farmers have to say, especially in connection with the GATT talks which, as I said earlier, are a matter of great concern to our farmers.
This proposal is acceptable, it does not violate existing treaties and it is legally votable. It seems to me we have a duty to support an idea that is as brilliant as it is practical. We often tend to go on at length about agriculture in the abstract, but listening to our farmers also means actively responding, with actions like this one, to their needs and expectations. I think Motion M-633 should be considered by our government, and I think the mover and the seconder of the motion fully deserve our congratulations. All parties here in the House should support this motion which, although modest in scale, will help our agricultural industry.
I think this motion should also be seen by the government as an example of how it could be more attuned, as was one of its members, to the needs of Canadians and above all how to introduce practical measures that could be immediately effective in supporting our agricultural industry, our dairy producers, our egg producers, our turkey producers, and also ensure that unfortunate consumer habits that are spreading in this country and affecting dairy products and products in the areas I just mentioned will stop and that consumers will stop and think about the product quality we have right here. To maintain that quality we must buy these products, which are often the same price and even better quality, and ensure the survival of our agriculture with practical measures like this one.
The Bloc Quebecois takes great pleasure in supporting the motion before the House, which is being debated for the last time today, and it will vote in favour of the motion.

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I am pleased to rise tonight to support the motion of the member for Perth-Wellington-Waterloo. It is time indeed that we take action on some of these issues that dramatically impact on the farmers of Canada, particularly those fanners of Canada who are not contributing to surpluses on the world markets.
This situation in which food is being brought in through cross-border shopping seriously undermines some of the most sophisticated marketing systems of any country in the world. Not only do we have those marketing systems but the food being sold under those marketing systems is also the highest quality of any country in the world, as a result of the inspection services we have here in Canada through Agriculture Canada, their inspectors and our own officials. The producers themselves are to be commended for the quality of food they produce. If people are paying less for food in the United States I can well understand why when I look at the differences in food quality between Canada and the United States.
These products being brought in are produced in an entirely different cost environment. I continue to keep tabs on the differences in costs between those of a dairy farmer in my own constituency and that of a county in Michigan, St. Clair County. Time and time again we have found that there is about a 25 per cent difference in the cost structure. This is a cost difference that our producers in Canada are powerless to do anything about.
Consequently, if we are going to have a viable industry in Canada a degree of protection must be provided. I believe this motion would go a long way toward providing it.
However, I do not accept the suggestion that this would be too difficult for the Minister for International Trade or the Minister of National Revenue to monitor. I can remember going across the border for years. If a person was there for more than 48 hours they were able to bring things back duty free. That was not difficult to monitor and this proposal would not be very difficult either. In fact, if we wanted to take a quart of milk into the U.S. I wonder how far we would get with it.
November 18, 1992

In view of the losses being incurred by the dairy farmers, particularly in the lower valley of British Columbia, in Ontario, in Quebec and in Atlantic Canada, this motion is long overdue. I hope it will be sent to committee tonight, be brought out very quickly and implemented as soon as possible so that the hurts and the cutbacks that are taking place in our industry at the present time do not have to continue.
Another thing we have to examine, and I have spoken about this quite a bit lately, is the current account deficit here in Canada. The Minister for International Trade loves to brag about the merchandise trade surplus but he does not say a word about the current account deficit. This money being spent outside of Canada is cash flowing out of Canada. Of course, that is part of the current account deficit. For every $20 billion in current account deficit we lose about 500,000 jobs in Canada. These are not my own figures, these are figures from prominent economists who have been studying this for quite some time.
This move alone would help get the government off the hook in terms of its current account deficit and what is happening to Canada because of it.
I also want to point out that here in Canada-I will go back to the year 1990 because that is the last year for which complete figures are available. We must look at the fact that it was about three years ago that the Minister of Agriculture started to talk not about the net farm income but the net family farm income in this House.
He pointed out that the average Canadian family farm income was almost $37,000, but out of that $37,000, $21,250 came from income earned either by the spouse or by the farmer himself working off the farm in some other industry to help supplement the farm income. That left a balance of about $15,500 in income from the farm itself. However, out of that figure $8,091 came from subsidies, either federal or provincial, leaving a net figure of about $7,400 from the farm operation itself.
Let me assure this House that the dairy farmers of Canada do not receive any subsidy at all for the fluid milk they produce. The only subsidy they receive is approximately $267 million for the industrial milk they produce, which is in turn made into cheese or skim milk powders and so on. This motion is really protecting the very viable industry which we have here in Canada including the poultry industry.
Private Members' Business
That average Canadian family farm income, and the net from the farm production alone of roughly $7,400, is a national disgrace. However, due to the marketing systems we have here the dairy farmers are not in that category. The dairy and poultry farmers are paying their way and they do not need any subsidy to do so. Look at their buildings and compare them with those of the dairy farmers of the United States and look at the poultry buildings here in Canada and make comparisons. It is an entirely different environment. For the good of all Canadians we should make sure that this motion passes as quickly as possible when it comes out of committee.
Another matter I want to touch upon and about which I am very concerned is health inspection in some of these institutions south of the border. We can look back at the deregulation that took place in the United States. It is on the books here. A deregulation of some of the regulations in Agriculture Canada was proposed last Friday by the Minister of Agriculture.
I am very concerned about it because we have the highest quality standards of any country in the world. When I look at some of the news media reports of what is happening in southern United States, and I will use the Atlanta Constitutional-Journal which did an ongoing study into health conditions in some of the poultry slaughtering plants in the United States, they indicate that conditions are absolutely deplorable.
Last Saturday night I was speaking in Bruce County to the Federation of Agriculture about this subject. One man in the audience rose and said: "You are exactly right. I am an inspector. I see truckloads of poultry coming into Canada from southern United States. In no way would it be allowed through a Canadian poultry processing plant".
There was a documentary on Prime Time Live last April 30 on the beef packing industry. We saw the conditions there. They would never be permitted in Canada. That would never be allowed to take place in Canada, under such deplorable conditions.
This bill not only protects the Canadian farmer but it protects the health of the Canadian consumer. Nobody is going to bring back some milk that is two days old or some chicken that is two or three days old, even though it could be sold over there. In this context, if we intend to keep control of the agricultural industry in Canada, if we intend to have our producers prosper, like any business they need a return on investment, management and risk.

Private Members' Business
As I look at the concentration in the agricultural industry in the United States at the present time, for example four firms control 45 per cent of the poultry produced and processed in the United States and four firms control 69 per cent of the beef produced and processed in the United States. We do not want to go that way. We must protect the Canadian family farm. It is the most viable institution we have for food production in the world. We have the highest quality food in any country in the world at a very reasonable price.
If food prices are too high here then I suggest to this House that we should look at the returns, the five-year average rate of returns of the Canadian dairy producers, which will range somewhere between 8 per cent and 10 per cent. We should compare that to other sectors of the food system, particularly the food distribution system with an average range of return of 17.2 per cent. It is not the farmers who are causing high prices.
I suggest this motion should be passed and sent on to committee immediately.

subtopic: CROSS-BORDER SHOPPING EXPORT AND IMPORT PERMITS
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I am delighted to have this opportunity to stand and speak in favour of the motion brought before this House by the hon. member from Waterloo.
It is not often I get a chance to agree with a member on the government side on an initiative and I am pleased to be able to do it on this particular one. The motion calls for an amendment to the Export and Import Permits Act to provide that importations under the authority of import permits, namely pertaining to dairy products, to chicken, turkeys and eggs, shall be subject to a mandatory 48-hour stay of the importer.
In other words, if Canadians go across the border to Washington to purchase these goods, they would have to stay for a 48-hour period in order to bring them back essentially duty free.
This motion goes some way toward resolving the problem. It will not eliminate the problem altogether. I am speaking from the perspective of a member from British Columbia. I might add that I have some 87 dairy producers in my riding of Okanagan-Shuswap as well as
a large number of poultry producers and egg producers. Many Canadians are doing this but I make reference in particular to British Columbians who are going across the border for same-day visits to purchase commodities such as cheaper gas, dairy products and poultry products south of the border. This has really caused a significant economic haemorrhaging from the economy of not only British Columbia but Canada as a whole.
Certainly one cannot blame people for trying to find the best deal possible. Every family has a budget to meet and a financial expectation to live up to. They are looking obviously for the best deal they can find. That has been made somewhat more difficult I might add the fact that these goods have been subjected to different taxation rates in terms of production and whatnot through the goods and services tax and different classes of production. We simply have to recognize that British Columbian farmers and Canadian farmers face higher costs of production than farmers who have different economic circumstances south of the border. There is a price difference between these commodities. A person cannot blame someone for trying to save a buck.
People do not think all the time about the economic consequences of moving that dollar south of the border and the kind of economic haemorrhaging that it causes our economy. When Canadians or British Columbians shop south of the border they are exporting jobs. That has hurt British Columbia. I would submit that it has had a fairly dramatic impact on the viability of our agricultural sector in British Columbia. I do not have the particular figures at my fingertips right now, but I know that there has been a significant loss in the millions of dollars in terms of losses to the agricultural industry.
What happens of course is that as people purchase products outside the country, the consumption of B.C. or Canadian dairy products goes down accordingly. Therefore, the quotas that are assessed the dairy farmer or the chicken producer or the egg producer are reduced accordingly. It is not only for farmers close to the border, but for farmers all over British Columbia. It affects the entire industry. That has had a fairly dramatic impact.
November 18, 1992

I do think that this particular amendment will have a modifying effect on the purchase of these particular goods outside of the province. I would suggest it would have a fairly significant impact on the viability of those industries and small farms in my riding of Okanagan- Shuswap, in ridings in the lower mainland, in the Fraser Valley and in the southern part of Vancouver Island.
Our economy in British Columbia is probably in better shape than in other parts of Canada, but there is no question that every time we lose a dollar to producers south of the border, we are essentially losing jobs. We are also losing tax revenues for both the provincial government and the federal government.
While we recognize, as I mentioned before, that consumers of course have every right to look for the best deal possible, I would hope that Canadians also recognize the importance of buying these products in Canada to support Canadian industries and to support the entire infrastructure. This has been put together to ensure that not only do consumers get fair prices but that the primary producers-the farmers and agriculturalists in Canada-have an opportunity to make a fair return on their investment.
It is a tough, tough business out there. Farming, agriculture and the return on investment is very low indeed. I think this government owes a responsibility to our Canadian fanners to do everything that it can to assist that industry to ensure that it remains viable and healthy in Canada.
I take pleasure in rising to support this particular motion and I congratulate the hon. member from Water-
Private Members' Business
loo for having the courage-because, of course, there is going to be some criticism of this motion-to recognize the problem and the courage to attempt to make an honourable approach to resolving this particular issue.
